class=\"toolbar-wrap js-toolbar-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"toolbar-inner-wrap\">\r\n                    <ul id=\"Toolbar\" role=\"navigation\">\r\n    <li class=\"toolbar-item class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>C Lemon, M W Auger, R McMahon, T Anguita, Y Apostolovski, G C-F Chen, C D Fassnacht, A D Melo, V Motta, A Shajib, T Treu, A Agnello, E Buckley-Geer, P L Schechter, S Birrer, T Collett, F Courbin, C E Rusu, T M C Abbott, S Allam, J Annis, S Avila, E Bertin, D Brooks, D L Burke, A Carnero\u00a0Rosell, M Carrasco\u00a0Kind, J Carretero, M Costanzi, L N da\u00a0Costa, J De\u00a0Vicente, S Desai, T F Eifler, B Flaugher, J Frieman, J Garc\u00eda-Bellido, E Gaztanaga, D W Gerdes, D Gruen, R A Gruendl, J Gschwend, G Gutierrez, K Honscheid, D J James, A Kim, E Krause, K Kuehn, N Kuropatkin, O Lahav, M Lima, H Lin, M A G Maia, M March, J L Marshall, F Menanteau, R Miquel, A Palmese, F Paz-Chinch\u00f3n, A A Plazas, A Roodman, E Sanchez, M Schubnell, S Serrano, M Smith, M Soares-Santos, E Suchyta, G Tarle, A R Walker,  The STRong lensing Insights into the Dark Energy Survey (STRIDES) 2017/2018 follow-up campaign: discovery of 10 lensed quasars and class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203028873 id=\"203028873\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the results of the STRong lensing Insights into the Dark Energy Survey (STRIDES) follow-up campaign of the late 2017/early 2018 season. We obtained spectra of 65 lensed quasar candidates with ESO Faint Object Spectrograph and Camera 2 on the NTT and Echellette Spectrograph and Imager on Keck, confirming 10 new lensed quasars and 10 quasar pairs. Eight lensed quasars are doubly imaged with source redshifts between 0.99 and 2.90, one is triply imaged (DESJ0345\u22122545, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.68), and one is quadruply imaged (quad: DESJ0053\u22122012, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.8). Singular isothermal ellipsoid models for the doubles, based on high-resolution imaging from SAMI on Southern Astrophysical Research Telescope or Near InfraRed Camera 2 on Keck, give total magnifications between 3.2 and 5.6, and Einstein radii between 0.49 and 1.97 arcsec. After spectroscopic follow-up, we extract multi-epoch <em>grizY</em> photometry of confirmed lensed quasars and contaminant quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star pairs from DES data using parametric multiband modelling, and compare variability in each system\u2019s components. By measuring the reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> associated with fitting all epochs to the same magnitude, we find a simple cut on the less variable component that retains all confirmed lensed quasars, while removing 94\u00a0per\u2009cent of contaminant systems. Based on our spectroscopic follow-up, this variability information improves selection of lensed quasars and quasar pairs from 34-45\u00a0per\u2009cent to 51\u201370\u00a0per\u2009cent, with most remaining contaminants being star-forming galaxies. Using mock lensed quasar light curves we demonstrate that selection based only on variability will over-represent the quad fraction by 10\u00a0per\u2009cent over a complete DES magnitude-limited sample, explained by the magnification bias and hence lower luminosity/more variable sources in quads.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: observational&quot;\">methods: observational</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: general&quot;\">quasars: general</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203028875 id=\"203028875\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The Dark Energy Survey (DES) has imaged over 5000\u2009deg<sup>2</sup> of extragalactic sky in the Southern hemisphere in five optical to near-infrared bands: <em>grizY</em>. Its depth and wide area provide the opportunity to discover rare objects (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Gravitationally lensed quasars are an example of such objects, with only \u223c200 known to date. Only a subset of this sample can be applied to certain science cases: time-delay cosmography requires lenses with long time delays (e.g. Saha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), well-separated images, and bright lensing galaxies (e.g. Treu\u00a0&amp; Koopmans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>); many microlensing studies ideally require pairs of images with short time delays (Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Blackburne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) or broad absorption line features (Hutsem\u00e9kers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Hutsem\u00e9kers, Sluse\u00a0&amp; Kumar <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Furthermore, to exploit the unique capabilities of observatories in the Northern and Southern hemispheres, it is important to discover lenses across the sky. The known number of lensed quasars in the North celestial hemisphere is more than double that in the South: 143\u201360,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> demonstrating the opportunity to mine lensed quasars from DES.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The STRong lensing Insights into the Dark Energy Survey (STRIDES<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup>) was set up to find gravitationally lensed quasars in the DES footprint (Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) for use as cosmological probes, with particular efforts on measuring time delays via the COSMOGRAIL collaboration (e.g. Courbin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). A sample of 40 well-studied time-delay lenses is expected to yield a 1\u00a0per\u2009cent precision measurement of the Hubble constant (Treu\u00a0&amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Shajib, Treu\u00a0&amp; Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Since there is not yet a complementary spectroscopic survey of the DES footprint, lens searches must be based on purely photometric data. Given also the lack of a <em>u</em> band in the DES wide field \u2013 a common component for selection of quasars below redshift \u223c2.7 \u2013 efficient selection techniques must rely on other resources. Previous STRIDES searches have used DES photometry and mid-infrared colours from the <em>Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</em> (<em>WISE</em>; Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), coupled with: catalogue-based or pixel-based machine learning (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), component-fitting to pixels (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and <em>Gaia</em> cross-matches to quasar candidates (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Ostrovski et\u00a0al. in preparation). These searches have yielded \u223c20 new gravitationally lensed quasars, including 4 quadruply imaged systems (hereafter quads), with one system already delivering time-delay cosmography inference (Shajib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019a</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present results from the STRIDES 2017\u20132018 follow-up campaign, pre-selecting candidates from the first 3 yr of DES imaging data. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we describe the lens selection techniques. Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> details the results of the spectroscopic and imaging follow-up of individual candidates, with discussion of several systems. After spectroscopic follow-up, we implement a parametric modelling procedure on DES single-epoch images in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a> to derive variability properties of lensed quasars and contaminants, discussing the possibility of implementing this to refine selection and improve lens search efficiency. We summarize the paper in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203028879 id=\"203028879\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 LENS SELECTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the variety of colours and morphologies of lensed quasars, individual selection techniques can be less effective in parts of this parameter space: for example, objects with bright lensing galaxies or quasars lensed by groups and clusters. It is therefore important to have several selection techniques each based on a different aspect of the DES data, or each including different external data sets. Our selection methods all rely on <em>WISE</em> photometry, in particular the 3.4 and 4.6\u2009\u00b5m bands (hereafter <em>W1</em> and <em>W2</em>). Lensed quasars are then selected via cross-matches to <em>Gaia</em> data release 1 (DR1) (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>), component fitting of the DES pixels (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>), or catalogued variability information from DES (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.3</a>). The techniques and selection procedures are described in this section, with their spectroscopic follow-up outcomes given in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028881 id=\"203028881\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 <em>Gaia</em> cross-matches</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Gaia</em>\u2019s high-resolution (0.1 arcsec FWHM), full-sky targeting of optically bright point sources makes it an ideal probe for resolving the multiple images of lensed quasars when ground-based data might blend them and catalogue a single object (Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>). <em>Gaia</em> DR1 was released on 2016 September 14, providing a single broad-band optical magnitude and high-precision astrometry for 1142\u2009679\u2009769 sources (Fabricius et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Lindegren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). We note that only <em>Gaia</em> DR1 was used for these selections due to the release date, however <em>Gaia</em> DR2 is more complete for detecting close-separation point sources (e.g. Arenou et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028883 id=\"203028883\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1-1>2.1.1 Method 1</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This selection method follows that of Lemon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), relying on multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections near <em>WISE</em>-selected candidate quasars, or single <em>Gaia</em> detections corresponding to extended DES objects. The latter technique was developed on account of <em>Gaia</em> DR1 often cataloguing only single components of lensed quasars (Ducourant et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We use the AllWISE catalogue, which is created from combining the cryogenic <em>WISE</em> and post-cryogenic NEOWISE survey data (Mainzer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The input catalogue for both searches is AllWISE detections with <em>W1</em>\u2212<em>W2</em>&gt; 0.5, <em>W1</em> &lt; 15.5, and catalogued uncertainties in <em>W1</em> and <em>W2</em>. The multiple-<em>Gaia</em>-detection search required at least two <em>Gaia</em> detections within 4 arcsec of the <em>WISE</em> source, and within 5 arcsec of each other. The single-<em>Gaia</em>-detection search required one <em>Gaia</em> detection within 4 arcsec of an extended DES object (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$MAG\\_PSF\\_I-MAG\\_AUTO\\_I\\gt 0.2$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$MAG\\_AUTO\\_I\\lt 20.5$|\u2060</span>). A stellar-density cut-off &lt;50\u2009000 <em>Gaia</em> detections per square degree was applied to both techniques to remove star clusters, resulting in 5996 and 43\u2009128 candidates, respectively. We note that the second data release of <em>Gaia</em> has complete detection of bright images of doubly lensed quasars, increasing the efficiency of such cross-matched lens searches (Lemon, Auger\u00a0&amp; McMahon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Candidates were visually inspected and graded according to Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.4</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028885 id=\"203028885\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1-2>2.1.2 Method 2</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This method is described by Agnello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and Agnello\u00a0&amp; Spiniello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), using pre-selection from <em>WISE</em> and astrometry from <em>Gaia</em> in two ways. The first is based on <em>WISE</em> pre-selection and deblending into <em>multiplets</em>, either in the <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 or DES catalogues. The second relies on astrometric offsets of objects across <em>Gaia</em> and 2MASS.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In the first search (following Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), objects with<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray}\r\nW1-W2\\gt 0.45+\\sqrt{\\delta W1^{2}+\\delta W2^{2}}\r\n\\end{eqnarray}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>were matched to <em>Gaia</em>-DR1, retaining only <em>WISE</em> sources that corresponded to at least two <em>Gaia</em><span class=\"monospace\">source</span> entries within a 6\u2009arcsec matching radius. After visual inspection, this resulted in the candidates and lenses presented by Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), where numbers of objects, multiplets and candidates at each stage are reported, and whose confirmation spectra are shown in this paper. A subset of the initial objects did not correspond to <em>Gaia</em> multiplets, but were deblended into multiple sources in the DES catalogue. After additional cuts in DES\u2212<em>WISE</em> colours and visual inspection, some were included in the multiplet sample (for further details we refer to Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), where they are presented).</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The second search (later described by Agnello\u00a0&amp; Spiniello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) used the same <em>WISE</em> pre-selection as above, but relied on the relative astrometry of the same sources in <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 and 2MASS to isolate quasars with nearby companions that were not deblended into <em>Gaia</em> multiplets. The main difference between that search and the implementation described by Agnello\u00a0&amp; Spiniello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) is that the latter used looser cuts in <em>WISE</em> colours to include candidates with a significant lens-galaxy contribution to the photometry. This search re-discovered candidates that were selected as DES multiplets (among <em>Gaia</em> singlets) in the first search.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028889 id=\"203028889\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Component fitting</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This selection technique follows that of Schechter et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and Anguita et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The initial list is taken from ALLWISE detections with <em>W1</em> &lt; 14.5 and <em>W1</em>\u2212<em>W2</em> &gt; 0.7. For each candidate, the best single-epoch image in each filter is fit as multiple quasi-Gaussians. To reject galaxies from the sample, quasi-Gaussians with widths larger than the local pipeline point spread function (PSF) are removed. For remaining systems with multiple bright components, two or three independent quasi-Gaussians are fit, and if at least two components are consistent with the local PSF, the system is retained. A colour selection, taking into account the possibility of reddening by a lensing galaxy, removes systems with very different optical colours, and a final selection is made by assigning Gaussian Mixture Model quasar probabilities from the <em>griz</em> colours following Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). This search is complementary to the <em>Gaia</em> searches as it is limited by the deeper DES depth.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028891 id=\"203028891\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Variability</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A number of physical processes have been proposed to explain quasar variability (see Schmidt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a> for examples and references). Irrespective of the physical process, we can use this intrinsic variability as a search technique. The technique was first proposed by Schmidt et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) as a way to detect quasars in wide-area sky surveys with no <em>u</em>-band imaging. They showed that with a survey such as the SDSS II Stripe 82, with \u223c60 epochs of imaging data over 5\u00a0yr, a variability selection could achieve a completeness and purity of 92\u00a0per\u2009cent, despite contaminants outnumbering true quasars by a factor of 30 in the input selection. Even with a much sparser sampling of 6 epochs over 3\u00a0yr, such as with Pan-STARRS1 (PS1; Chambers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), the variability method gave a 30\u00a0per\u2009cent pure and 75\u00a0per\u2009cent complete quasar candidate sample from a <em>griz</em>-selected input catalogue, which included the stellar locus, and a 92\u00a0per\u2009cent pure and 44\u00a0per\u2009cent complete quasar sample after removing the stellar locus. The method has also been successfully used to select a sample of high-redshift quasars in the SDSS III BOSS survey (Palanque-Delabrouille et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). As the first 3 yr of DES data have a similar number of epochs as PS1 (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), we should expect similar results for isolated quasars. We should note, however, that the behaviour for lensed quasars may not be exactly the same as for isolated quasars due to microlensing.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For our lensed quasar search we follow the method described by Schmidt et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and Palanque-Delabrouille et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). In order to create an input sample on which to apply the variability algorithm we begin with the <em>WISE</em> catalogue and select objects with <em>W2</em> &lt; 14.45 and <em>W1</em> \u2212 <em>W2</em> &gt; 0.5 on the Vega system. The selection yields 335\u2009345 objects. For each object that is selected from the <em>WISE</em> catalogue we then match it to an object in the DES Year 3 catalogue using a matching radius of 4 arcsec. As the <em>WISE</em> resolution is significantly worse than that of DES, there could be more than one DES object matched to the single <em>WISE</em> detection. For each matched object we extract all the single-epoch detections of that object in <em>griz</em> and use them to compute the variability. For each pair of observations <em>i</em> and <em>j</em> in a given band we define a magnitude difference \u0394<em>m<sub>i,j</sub></em>\u00a0= <em>m<sub>i</sub></em> \u2212 <em>m<sub>j</sub></em>, where <em>m<sub>i</sub></em> and <em>m<sub>j</sub></em> are the magnitudes of the individual detections, and a time difference \u0394<em>t<sub>i,j</sub></em>\u00a0= <em>t<sub>i</sub></em> \u2212 <em>t<sub>j</sub></em>, where <em>t<sub>i</sub></em> and <em>t<sub>j</sub></em> are the epochs of the observations. We assume a power-law increase of the variability as a function of the time difference: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray}\r\nV_{\\text{mod}}(\\Delta t_{i,j}|A,\\gamma) = A(\\Delta t_{i,j}/1\\, \\textrm{yr})^{\\gamma },\r\n\\end{eqnarray}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>where <em>A</em> is the variability amplitude and \u03b3 is the power-law index. We fit this model to the set of data (\u0394<em>m<sub>i,j</sub></em>, \u0394<em>t<sub>i,j</sub></em>) by maximizing <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L} = \\prod _{i,j} L_{i,j}$|\u2060</span>, where <em>L</em> is defined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray}\r\nL_{i,j} = \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2\\pi V_{\\mathrm{ obs},i,j}^2}}\\exp \\left(-\\frac{\\Delta m_{i,j}^2}{2 V_{\\mathrm{ obs},i,j}^2}\\right) .\r\n\\end{eqnarray}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$V_{\\mathrm{ obs},i,j}^2$|</span> is the observed variability and is equal to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$V_{\\mathrm{ mod}}(\\Delta t_{i,j}|A,\\gamma)^2 + (\\sigma _i^2 + \\sigma _j^2)$|\u2060</span>. The quantities \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> and \u03c3<sub><em>j</em></sub> are the measured uncertainties on <em>m<sub>i</sub></em> and <em>m<sub>j</sub></em>. We require that an object is detected in at least 4 epochs in an individual band and then fit for <em>A</em> and \u03b3 for that band. We do this for all four bands. For objects that have at least 4 epochs and a good fit in at least three of the available bands we then follow the method of Palanque-Delabrouille et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and we fit for a single value of \u03b3 in all bands and different values of <em>A</em> (<em>A<sub>g</sub>, A<sub>r</sub>, A<sub>i</sub>, A<sub>z</sub></em>).</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For each object we require that it passes the following quasar selection cuts in three out of the four bands. <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\gamma \\gt 0.5\\log (A) + 0.50 \\ , \\ \\gamma \\gt -2\\log (A) - 2.25 \\ , \\ \\gamma \\gt 0.055.\r\n\\end{eqnarray}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>This process results in 16\u2009026 objects. These objects are then analysed using the image splitting technique described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>. We also looked explicitly at systems where there were two or more DES objects matched to the <em>WISE</em> object and retained those where at least two of the objects passed the selection criteria of equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ4\"></span><a href=\"#equ4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>) in at least three of the bands.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In total, we selected 56 new objects for spectroscopic and imaging follow-up. These objects were visually inspected. The method also recovered five known lensed quasars which were previously discovered by other STRIDES techniques. These five were not included in the 56. The 56 objects are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> where we show the values of <em>A<sub>g</sub>, A<sub>r</sub>, A<sub>i</sub>, A<sub>z</sub></em> versus \u03b3 for each object.</p>                        <a id=\"203028896\" scrollto-destination=\"203028896\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=uKV86A73hqa~0A2xhipoy4sNir2R5XTSocL1epMnQCMOQ7HwdjODQWs1WhC7yjTs0U8dmmQ97mKOCl50tZ0~-Exi~WsAgwniqtyb9zZ1Am6q5U5a7gbS2yrPnQXBz1f8gkjZXNaWQ0CMiQ3d4oiqmKAZEcLekYFjj9HbZpkEOtDHCnSRjrZVTLwGoGS3XU8U1A6uQoKwp8p9eSc25HDUxRt9zuFbCcWqNtaM6-Vi4mD~lTgSK-iQm~xBGSMd8btbbhZal1MkUemMpXCwHJGL~skCDHfaONlTcSeB1tGEv8341EvsGZBT5cxXXcgUeYe1hV-z4-V7cSL~mtltycOEwQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of variability amplitude, A, versus power-law index, \u03b3, for the 56 variability-selected candidates. Known lensed quasars are shown in red.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028896/staa652fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028896\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=YuYhctI6y6ZPTAFd9Z~ob0DQx5n8unWo15TIUb3jW5FjNVX6cN5HYWw95J-rthd6TreZmDqE3eUWqEWm~a6ZF8mn8M358gwZrHURiM55GIoyFYQmT9VUjg9NaTYy8xPAPuwbqMf7FlZ~BqkQS58LOhzV64Q0WX-1g8oqYjjioCPP7jA3jCJp04SKTAnc4tsWS~xzJ65K~eGIRLBYwVXpjCLymm0ZcgoNkSvPer~aiC4sCBmXQA8QaP7N37UM~yJNIdzi9yOX9BQ6b-7G6uLUfOTuQj0r6tGe7j92BCj5krOvP-JMpLk2icJTlu1dXP25X6Vqur73rFNVz7NU4r5f1A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028896&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of variability amplitude, <em>A</em>, versus power-law index, \u03b3, for the 56 variability-selected candidates. Known lensed quasars are shown in red.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=uKV86A73hqa~0A2xhipoy4sNir2R5XTSocL1epMnQCMOQ7HwdjODQWs1WhC7yjTs0U8dmmQ97mKOCl50tZ0~-Exi~WsAgwniqtyb9zZ1Am6q5U5a7gbS2yrPnQXBz1f8gkjZXNaWQ0CMiQ3d4oiqmKAZEcLekYFjj9HbZpkEOtDHCnSRjrZVTLwGoGS3XU8U1A6uQoKwp8p9eSc25HDUxRt9zuFbCcWqNtaM6-Vi4mD~lTgSK-iQm~xBGSMd8btbbhZal1MkUemMpXCwHJGL~skCDHfaONlTcSeB1tGEv8341EvsGZBT5cxXXcgUeYe1hV-z4-V7cSL~mtltycOEwQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of variability amplitude, A, versus power-law index, \u03b3, for the 56 variability-selected candidates. Upper left g band; upper right r band; lower left i band; lower right z band. Known lensed quasars are shown in red.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028896/staa652fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028896\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=YuYhctI6y6ZPTAFd9Z~ob0DQx5n8unWo15TIUb3jW5FjNVX6cN5HYWw95J-rthd6TreZmDqE3eUWqEWm~a6ZF8mn8M358gwZrHURiM55GIoyFYQmT9VUjg9NaTYy8xPAPuwbqMf7FlZ~BqkQS58LOhzV64Q0WX-1g8oqYjjioCPP7jA3jCJp04SKTAnc4tsWS~xzJ65K~eGIRLBYwVXpjCLymm0ZcgoNkSvPer~aiC4sCBmXQA8QaP7N37UM~yJNIdzi9yOX9BQ6b-7G6uLUfOTuQj0r6tGe7j92BCj5krOvP-JMpLk2icJTlu1dXP25X6Vqur73rFNVz7NU4r5f1A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028896&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of variability amplitude, <em>A</em>, versus power-law index, \u03b3, for the 56 variability-selected candidates. Upper left <em>g</em> band; upper right <em>r</em> band; lower left <em>i</em> band; lower right <em>z</em> band. Known lensed quasars are shown in red.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028897 id=\"203028897\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4>2.4 Final candidate selection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">After visual inspection of each method\u2019s final candidate list by one author (<em>Gaia</em> 1: CL, <em>Gaia</em> 2: AA, component fitting: PS, variability: EBG), any possible lensed quasars were given a ranking from 0 to 3. 3 was reserved for targets that must be followed up based on all photometric evidence suggesting it is a lens, 2 for probable lens candidates, 1 for possible lens candidates, and 0 for unlikely lens candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While we still have many unobserved targets, all Rank 3 and most Rank 2 candidates were followed up either spectroscopically, or with high-resolution imaging, or both. This follow-up is detailed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203028900 id=\"203028900\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 RESULTS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028901 id=\"203028901\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Spectroscopy</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectroscopic follow-up was performed using grism #13 on the ESO Faint Object Spectrograph and Camera 2 (EFOSC2) on the NTT over the nights of 2017 October 21\u201323 <span class=\"small-caps\">ut</span> and 2018 January 7\u20139 (Program ID: 0100.A-0297, PI: Anguita) providing a resolution of \u223c5.5\u2009\u00c5\u2009pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> (with 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02 binning read-out). The Echellette Spectrograph and Imager (ESI; Sheinis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) on Keck 2 on the nights of 2017 November 18\u201319 <span class=\"small-caps\">ut</span> was also used, in the default Echellette mode providing a resolution of \u223c0.35\u2009\u00c5\u2009pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> at the central orders (Program ID: 2017B_U110, PI: Fassnacht).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All 2D background-subtracted spectra were visually inspected to confirm broad emission lines (or lack thereof) in the multiple spatially resolved components, and 1D spectra were extracted using Gaussian apertures of widths dependent on the seeing. Spectra of confirmed lensed quasars are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> (with their DES <em>gri</em> colour cut-outs shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>), and spectra of quasar pairs in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"203028904\" scrollto-destination=\"203028904\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=NhG74GOJb-EmuBT2m7lHhmAUUlufor3WvaUcaarbvndPnwwr9cYSXFEAN623A9Gwm15dvvvWusdSYC1VwIG6tji2yjTWSirC-C747E2jaySpYzLhAeZu-1hW9oj1cO61btUJB0VcsacqQNEcQ8CcMqat7U-ZfPPJWrp2Kk5jpQSQt~FY2CYk6Jn2tExEwrQRITeIAbPR2OUzk1Wto8J6PxzUqpZASApAaXpjKBoN1PL0tIQbTUp~HzdDTsnwNhJsrtmhTwUs~0AeDBMRlX7LWjutP5tgd6aW-NWrHi-bjwEQPS9DfdhVLIGkcTE~z19GXYml6ntJfAL5oVkMiBxEQA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spatially resolved spectra of quasar images of the confirmed lensed quasars. Beneath each panel is a flux ratio against wavelength plot to aid comparison of spectra. For DESJ0053\u22122012 the flux ratio is between images A and B.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028904/staa652fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028904\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=N5RzErx9jXL27Gwun2dGTjvsF5Bnv7Dei6tkE11IIHk7uKvsAM-MGPNzjhBl8qbJor2K-~p51E~Jrfa0JH0E3f-TmQfqsf4rtNpKxP58VG0mpzzDeoFlMIGKe3THm~smCHG6lRVtQop2qxzeVloOZaYz85GE-2VGvqtjOoHj~vQz0KauUsx1EPKeJA6w9Zfj3GrG0GeKClNjlifuamczCla1mTkKZ5fEFjoD-XyvO9yIZ~t~ZK~pN6v3yJJvU0KMoTJKAhHgjFmEruElMBe2vMaBnmUa~aYEZ4HnwqVsVIUScLXwKhxm0XyuntOqRj2394Vu5lxQDRNDOaxSwLA~6Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028904&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spatially resolved spectra of quasar images of the confirmed lensed quasars. The flux is in arbitrary units and in some cases the spectra have been offset to aid comparison of the spectra. Beneath each panel is a flux ratio against wavelength plot to aid comparison of spectra.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028907 id=\"203028907\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 High-resolution imaging</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Four systems were observed using the Near InfraRed Camera 2 (NIRC2) on Keck-2 (PI: Treu, Program ID: U049), and 33 observed using the Southern Astrophysical Research Telescope (SOAR) Adaptive optics Module Imager (SAMI; PIs: Motta and Treu, programs: 1005 and 0138, respectively), as listed in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>, and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA2\" data-open=\"tblA2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a>. The data reduction and modelling for the two data sets are described as follows.</p>                        <a id=\"203028909\" scrollto-destination=\"203028909\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Confirmed lensed quasars. NIQ\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203028910\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028911 id=\"203028911\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-1>3.2.1 NIRC2</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DESJ0245\u22120556, DESJ0246\u22121845, DESJ0340\u22122545, and DESJ0508\u22122748 were observed with the NIRC2 narrow camera, giving a 10\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010 arcsec<sup>2</sup> field of view and 10 mas\u2009pixels. Observations were taken in the <em>K</em> band in order to maximize AO correction. Since there are no other stars to estimate the PSF in the field of the narrow camera, we reconstruct the PSF based on the data. While this can lead to fitting real structures such as host galaxy light \u2013 particularly degenerate for doubles \u2013 using analytical profiles often leaves significant residuals at the cores of PSFs where we would expect the lensed host galaxy to be brightest (Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The PSF reconstruction is performed for each set of position and galaxy parameters, for a square PSF grid (with pixel sizes the same as the data) and linear interpolation, as described by Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The reconstructed PSF from the best-fitting model is used for convolution with the Sersic galaxy profiles. Since this PSF might not represent the true PSF, and due to atmospheric variations between frames, we include a positional uncertainty of 5 mas (half a pixel) in quadrature on our sampled statistical uncertainty. DESJ0508\u22122748 is fit to the noise with 2 PSFs and since it has a blended spectrum in both ESI and EFOSC2 data we label the system as inconclusive (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4-7\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4-7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4.7</a>). The other three candidates observed by NIRC2 are lensed quasars, with their data, PSF subtractions, and model subtractions shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"203028913\" scrollto-destination=\"203028913\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=15DU8XVVVd8JJ4JLTdj2azBAFK8dZik8bnhBDka37dMsMzN57gG-yj7FnRCOA~skMWPYNx00YrUBgIjyoPY4BGEiNbe3KnE5g~X9F3TLozpkcFpuodB5bvCj~dxtoCtoaxnwDlxfGwX002bUcOwJ2jbr3xDrkcCOgVzzbBxziyMRMeJNHzujH5C~nTz7TbOfR9Cj~tC7IABFibQFj9T-qb3tomkl2psCqkExX1IUD3wGju255Q9~g8WoY15r8wr2I37zsshNSU0u-SX1XUpe~SqAD-yMC4OorNRN8PkxzGDPbxYzzcldIG4mYoy3o5lzTCSxfm7L-4WyborXc7ijNA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"NIRC2 AO data for confirmed lensed quasars. From left to right: Data, model, PSFs subtracted, and PSFs and galaxy subtracted. The white scale bar is 0.5 arcsec, and labels refer to sources listed in Table\u00a0B1. North is up, East is left. Flux is displayed using the cubehelix colour scheme (Green 2011).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028913/staa652fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028913\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=cJbpopowNKPusclLJ3V5bs9v24Se9BBeIu~1ejmtofosQ5peZi7F4ffCX05LHqGqfUshiFFynnnQdYLG~OuzZyIhiPmDsvtizBNbGTzPpcitLFnKzBFXaD~LmPBG1NZhX~m47KG3y-~xxbD1NAVDpLD-7xcahdSLsbm7uuN4VofWO~OyV9aUGE3W8uU3F6S4B1zREFRZXL5lebTzaWAiNhbkFQ-C77kPZPh-RzOb9dj9niS0W9vvtLeBSVSFTyEjOBKEwvUxovKroY6Z7awPiH1V1ECgkaw3~Q9mVwCtBnro1-KR8eMY5KnBINvk8mzv4TUtqma5DMkGMfn~-IKcCQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028913&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">NIRC2 AO data for confirmed lensed quasars. Flux is displayed using the cubehelix colour scheme (Green 2011).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028913/staa652fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028913\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=cJbpopowNKPusclLJ3V5bs9v24Se9BBeIu~1ejmtofosQ5peZi7F4ffCX05LHqGqfUshiFFynnnQdYLG~OuzZyIhiPmDsvtizBNbGTzPpcitLFnKzBFXaD~LmPBG1NZhX~m47KG3y-~xxbD1NAVDpLD-7xcahdSLsbm7uuN4VofWO~OyV9aUGE3W8uU3F6S4B1zREFRZXL5lebTzaWAiNhbkFQ-C77kPZPh-RzOb9dj9niS0W9vvtLeBSVSFTyEjOBKEwvUxovKroY6Z7awPiH1V1ECgkaw3~Q9mVwCtBnro1-KR8eMY5KnBINvk8mzv4TUtqma5DMkGMfn~-IKcCQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028913&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">NIRC2 AO data for confirmed lensed quasars. From left to right: Data, model, PSFs subtracted, and PSFs and galaxy subtracted. The white scale bar is 0.5 arcsec, and labels refer to sources listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblB1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblB1\" data-open=\"tblB1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>. North is up, East is left. Flux is displayed using the cubehelix colour scheme (Green <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028914 id=\"203028914\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-2>3.2.2 SOAR</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Thirty-three candidates were observed with the SAMI instrument with its AO system SAM (Tokovinin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Imaging was carried out in the <em>z</em> band to maximize AO correction and optimize the contrast between quasar images and possible lensing galaxies. The pixel scale was 0.09 arcsec\u2009pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> (2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02 binning of 0.045 arcsec\u2009pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>) and the typical exposure time was 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0180\u00a0s.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the large field of view (3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03 arcmin<sup>2</sup>), nearby stars were used to fit Moffat profiles. When a good fit was achieved the Moffat parameters were used for the PSF model of the candidate system. If this PSF left visually obvious residuals, the Moffat parameters were included as part of the modelling of the system and simultaneously inferred with the galaxy and image parameters. If this was still left significant residuals, a nearby star was used, and pixel shifts were computed via a spline interpolation. All quasar pairs and inconclusive candidates, as listed in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>, respectively, were consistent with two PSFs when modelling the SOAR data (or as a PSF and galaxy in the case of DESJ0402\u22124220). The data, PSF subtractions, and model subtractions for lenses without NIRC2 data are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"203028917\" scrollto-destination=\"203028917\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=I9o1LRv5pwlKxshpIZW0vDnScVEHkXJHZDoK8O1f01mD3pWvMPGiQ2A9AaOSyxxG~8acTDW5CdmvHDA7CS8aadsivMXyJ-0mus6pIDPJOE~4tpz0Qlmi-cJQhmmNte06IBeCKEM6WQNOxA0d2tLAaMy3r9uX9KiplU5FVatrqVAiPsZg0Lr2INR-PTfzxYbXHFdd8pfz~PruleAOSwQQwPsQj1pPssGQfSOX2s39cdbqzaLvs24HtcjVcVc0lIQOynAjnKScYye33w4gllnyZbstobjaV8pchuZHRnn~EdbbjwXdPokdDxPpMG2dSjCJ1-Lyh0i07N4qFHZfEh-7Tw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: SOAR z-band cut-outs for confirmed lensed quasars; middle: PSF subtracted images; right: PSF and galaxies subtracted. Cut-outs are 9 arcsec on the side. North is up, East is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028917/staa652fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028917\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=hO0ZK6P5TAaKKqVoIeCGttjEaGoafs5Jp18dhBKyMY7xLo7X951ws9DnHJaZfwUdUSeLnfav-Lc6mduVbsGELygp-IzYVw5HiaNIZ1kVdF-cu6uMcCFCGuaZDNfSVcznbuCASjjDUoZqYaQhm0s4cg~X-i7IQ580NaWPbWT2XFVT7~WwFRcDdiSEzj5Nda6gADXAbfxeMvMjdrrdnyj0ODA9~lkANTN1cY9YBuaY-KcNRIeHbNLaGrWMUsT1MDF0kwpeGvdRcZQhxl6ZbfEytDbZo~~SzTdUGXYx1MLIkcok8EpUy6tOUGAziCiYEA4tbNVLaqbSan-Tv7tifstTcA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028917&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Left: SOAR <em>z</em>-band cut-outs for confirmed lensed quasars; middle: PSF subtracted images; right: PSF and galaxies subtracted. Cut-outs are 9 arcsec on the side. North is up, East is left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=I9o1LRv5pwlKxshpIZW0vDnScVEHkXJHZDoK8O1f01mD3pWvMPGiQ2A9AaOSyxxG~8acTDW5CdmvHDA7CS8aadsivMXyJ-0mus6pIDPJOE~4tpz0Qlmi-cJQhmmNte06IBeCKEM6WQNOxA0d2tLAaMy3r9uX9KiplU5FVatrqVAiPsZg0Lr2INR-PTfzxYbXHFdd8pfz~PruleAOSwQQwPsQj1pPssGQfSOX2s39cdbqzaLvs24HtcjVcVc0lIQOynAjnKScYye33w4gllnyZbstobjaV8pchuZHRnn~EdbbjwXdPokdDxPpMG2dSjCJ1-Lyh0i07N4qFHZfEh-7Tw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: SOAR z-band cut-outs for confirmed lensed quasars; middle: PSF subtracted images; right: PSF and galaxies subtracted. North is up, East is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028917/staa652fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028917\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=hO0ZK6P5TAaKKqVoIeCGttjEaGoafs5Jp18dhBKyMY7xLo7X951ws9DnHJaZfwUdUSeLnfav-Lc6mduVbsGELygp-IzYVw5HiaNIZ1kVdF-cu6uMcCFCGuaZDNfSVcznbuCASjjDUoZqYaQhm0s4cg~X-i7IQ580NaWPbWT2XFVT7~WwFRcDdiSEzj5Nda6gADXAbfxeMvMjdrrdnyj0ODA9~lkANTN1cY9YBuaY-KcNRIeHbNLaGrWMUsT1MDF0kwpeGvdRcZQhxl6ZbfEytDbZo~~SzTdUGXYx1MLIkcok8EpUy6tOUGAziCiYEA4tbNVLaqbSan-Tv7tifstTcA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028917&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Left: SOAR <em>z</em>-band cut-outs for confirmed lensed quasars; middle: PSF subtracted images; right: PSF and galaxies subtracted. Cut-outs are 9 arcsec on the side. North is up, East is left.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028918 id=\"203028918\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Lens modelling</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the measured image and galaxy positions, we are able to construct simple mass models for our confirmed lenses. NIRC2 and SOAR positions are used for all lenses except for DESJ0112\u22121650 and DESJ2349\u22124518, which lack high-resolution imaging. For these systems we use the DES data, which are modelled as in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. For the eight doubly imaged systems, we use a singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE; Kormann, Schneider\u00a0&amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>) to understand the basic properties of the system, such as Einstein radius and magnification. However, the inferred mass flattening is highly degenerate with the external shear, hence we set the latter to zero. Furthermore, we must use the flux ratio of the quasar images so we are not overfitting the data: seven measurements (quasar image positions, galaxy position, and flux ratio) are used to fit seven parameters (source position, galaxy position, Einstein radius, and mass axial ratio and position angle). Since these optical flux ratios may be strongly affected by microlensing or variability over the time delay, we increase their uncertainties by 20\u00a0per\u2009cent in quadrature with the sampled statistical uncertainties. As there are 0 degrees of freedom, we expect \u03c7<sup>2</sup> values of 0. Any discrepancy from this implies that the model is not a good description of the data. This might be caused by a complex mass distribution, or flux ratio anomalies due to substructure or microlensing, and so we report the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> contributions from galaxy position, image positions, and flux ratios separately for each lens system in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, alongside the mass model parameters. Due to the simplicity of a single SIE, our models can only hint at some true physical properties of the lens system, such as magnification, or whether a large shear is expected for the system due to a large mismatch between the modelled mass position angle and axial ratio and that of the light, which has been shown to be similar for many systems with shear properly accounted for (Shajib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019b</a>). For the triply imaged system, DESJ0340\u22122545, and the quad, DESJ0053\u22122012, we explore more complex mass models as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"203028920\" scrollto-destination=\"203028920\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Median parameter values with 1\u03c3 uncertainties for mass model and galaxy light profiles of confirmed lensed quasars. <em>b</em>\u00a0=\u00a0Einstein radius, PA\u00a0=\u00a0position angle (East of North), <em>q</em> = axial ratio, and \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a0magnification. Given the group lensing DESJ0340\u22122545, more detailed mass models are described in the text and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> for this system. The model we use for DESJ0053\u22122012 is a 2 SIE model, as described in the text. For this model, we expect a good fit to have \u03c7<sup>2</sup> \u2248 3.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203028920\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028921 id=\"203028921\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Notes on individual objects</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028922 id=\"203028922\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4-1>3.4.1 DESJ0053\u22122012</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system is the only confirmed quad from the 2017/2018 follow-up campaign. It was selected by the <em>Gaia</em>-<em>WISE</em> selection of Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1.1</a> as a <em>Gaia</em> DR1 double (<em>G</em>\u00a0=\u00a019.21, 19.43) corresponding to a red <em>WISE</em> detection (<em>W1</em>\u2212<em>W2</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.55). The redshift of the system is <em>z</em> \u2248 3.8. It is not more precisely determined due to the strong absorption of Lyman \u03b1.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A SIE\u00a0+\u00a0shear model is insufficient to reproduce the positions and flux ratios, providing a best-fitting \u03c7<sup>2</sup> \u2248 30 for 4 degrees of freedom. The model requires a strong shear of 0.22, 159\u2009deg East of North, while the companion galaxy G2 is 4.3 arcsec 131\u2009deg East of North. We choose to explicitly model G2 as an SIE with shape fixed to that of the light (as measured in the <em>z</em>-band SOAR data), and leave the Einstein radius as a free parameter. This new model provides a best-fitting \u03c7<sup>2</sup>\u00a0= 2.43 for 3 degrees of freedom, now requiring a shear of 0.13, 20\u2009deg East of North. The caustics and critical curves of this model are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. The main contribution to the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> is from the flux ratios, with B being 25\u00a0per\u2009cent fainter than predicted. This is consistent with the expectations of microlensing suppression since this image is a saddle point (Schechter\u00a0&amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). While G1 is approximately 20\u00a0per\u2009cent brighter than G2 in the <em>z</em>-band imaging, the modelled Einstein radii are 1.13 and 1.17 arcsec, respectively. Though faint, the galaxies do appear to have different colours in the DES data, suggesting the two galaxies are at different redshifts, however spectroscopic redshift identification is required for this system to be used for time-delay cosmography. We note that, assuming a lens redshift of 0.7, expected time delays are 22, 26, and 137\u00a0d, in the expected image ordering ACBD.</p>                        <a id=\"203028925\" scrollto-destination=\"203028925\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=X7k6CrLYUs9Jwx-kdmE3vv9pkwj~KhXQ-eTlXD2Yh4cfVy5w9NZ2~i-FQGI71v8bY7e3MsBdtYwIYhLE6s90UcYE6icldL5h-kM4uYLYOSwvXTNfgxT2xcCU8sA6Re-YQKU3QksorvlRvFaTF6X84pXUnwLKdacPGSPb-5BWdlAG5GXKDDdgc9Vid0lm1rMh218j-oQVoOOjb-2dhJsYk0ZayjtWIEBSn29vp~nqHQXocbcDNpE7WPIpO7r7I47OgFIk0hdonIGseK8qtAZz4hIyKmeVk4U6aDYsatpRvnBzaOs5SS4gGwySkP5deRlYamQz-k7HuiL855qq-8JvxA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DESJ0053\u22122012 best-fitting model. Left: Source plane caustics with source position overlaid in red. Right: Image plane critical curves with measured image positions, and best-fitting model image positions overlaid, with area representing flux. North is up, East is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028925/staa652fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028925\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=PfgzotLIVT7Ntjt-hazVVPNynYRD9XT8GTW5RZhMSmMvBHU1tltGkvZZ9ipRqMhIIm1TQIY3hhtca5Du5XF7T5uAi1jwwcrO9gdOHByIWg0FEVX1PdDjsbkPJssETIDBbUA3znG3~dzyQvs3fuNXk0dLNRmBjq8FW8iE06Pyv5fFq1bWeiRweB2PxN9IoRLEPYhB4U9uDa0MgE9Fr43BDNx6nePqfDctz-2iGrMQVB0FXrNZvmBj90n5RTfNO1Sv5t6fdIqIaFKc63SOdNx5V0zqeDXy5SL61SM3~QkTmoQeaPr7etc1HE2H~iCLdVuhy5V7H-vp9XnF2J8Nv-jVVA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028925&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DESJ0053\u22122012 best-fitting model. Left: Source plane caustics with source position overlaid in red. Right: Image plane critical curves with measured image positions, and best-fitting model image positions overlaid, with area representing flux. North is up, East is left.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028926 id=\"203028926\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4-2>3.4.2 DESJ0112\u22121650</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Resolved ESI spectra show two quasars with very similar spectra at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.99. There is absorption due to a massive galaxy seen in both quasar images at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.52 (from Ca H, K, G, and Na at 6063, 6116, 6635, and 9084 \u00c5, respectively), which is a promising sign of a lensing galaxy. While we lack high-resolution imaging of this system, the DES data clearly shows a redder object offset from the line joining the two blue point sources. This is often seen with fold quad configurations, where the faint counterimage is either highly reddened or the data are not deep enough, while one of the observed PSFs is a pair of close images, as was observed in the cases of PSJ0030-1525 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) or SDSSJ1330+1810 (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). We model the system as two point sources, and subsequently as three point sources, which both show an extended galaxy in the residuals. Therefore, we adopt three point sources and a galaxy (Sersic profile) as the fiducial pixel model for this system, as this fits the data without any obvious residual structures (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>). We currently cannot determine whether the third point source, C, is a highly reddened quasar image, a foreground star, or structure due to the lensing galaxy. Our mass model given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> assumes only A and B are quasar images, with G being the only lensing galaxy. The mean reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> values for A, B, and C from multi-epoch modelling (as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>) are 6.72, 5.42, and 2.74, respectively. However, this does not imply C is necessarily less variable, since its photometric uncertainties are larger relative to the brighter components, A and B. The value is consistent with those from stars in quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star systems and should not be taken as a detection of variability. High-resolution imaging is required to clarify the nature of this system.</p>                        <a id=\"203028928\" scrollto-destination=\"203028928\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=iqDr8oNR72nwbHybdOivW7~Y0yKb7Aev9ms9eVdqJnKNT2Fu28QGAMrGL8YtsFrhFxmtpRk5V~5DxmPViLICFw9N3qg0ADU9FfS7rai1qL3tEfQiIwCxUeqqfSKQOYsVpzv4Rl-9MHoJUDhFswOFaPzhxIAPJ~pAk4np4HOCeYVBsPUdQ6KxZWe9mRsC6CtbmjMJo6SLuC0bkNEygA2WAH5jRnSpqYPxqPglOj7eHuqksKADj7EPoYMqsbWgEI4kZaZxaHKD-MnYhi4TUAwphRsRhrNMV8K-ou~WFlaUix8pQajFc8DS-eSrLl6ql8u~brgoWlCvcu2BZCAulBwYIQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"J0112\u22121650 gri stacked models from single-epoch images. The white scale bar is 2 arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028928/staa652fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028928\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=EELXDJKByvNVLIv~Z6fgVJqLWhCLDs9tZDH722Qv4I-J8WcUwIGzuao6heTQUnzuiDhxQb-~szjlBFN0aBrngQvWDapaUxw9k4vGaEc18Vr0phIIHWMAJLYJj0kaQUsw1FjHcsd3nzyjR~uZU1c6f6UwslQ1K88eo~gXV7wkYPWAojR92DE3CRITSV-YAAEmJMg7GM9LOOB8vAgjyu4mi2tbWMmsf2HDmtP3swU1CMPPdKB8MDOhhtO3Jy8n8WtWbS5MFWJLspkVRkJNL7lM8f3NHipPl7stjL6CHixlU6f4ffLHL-1CpmSvp1zBsAG0r9dSNAHwDKzi2YyRZLWU5A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028928&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">J0112\u22121650 <em>gri</em> stacked models from single-epoch images. The white scale bar is 2 arcsec.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=iqDr8oNR72nwbHybdOivW7~Y0yKb7Aev9ms9eVdqJnKNT2Fu28QGAMrGL8YtsFrhFxmtpRk5V~5DxmPViLICFw9N3qg0ADU9FfS7rai1qL3tEfQiIwCxUeqqfSKQOYsVpzv4Rl-9MHoJUDhFswOFaPzhxIAPJ~pAk4np4HOCeYVBsPUdQ6KxZWe9mRsC6CtbmjMJo6SLuC0bkNEygA2WAH5jRnSpqYPxqPglOj7eHuqksKADj7EPoYMqsbWgEI4kZaZxaHKD-MnYhi4TUAwphRsRhrNMV8K-ou~WFlaUix8pQajFc8DS-eSrLl6ql8u~brgoWlCvcu2BZCAulBwYIQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"J0112\u22121650 gri stacked models from single-epoch images.
