The white scale bar is 2 arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028928/staa652fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028928\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=EELXDJKByvNVLIv~Z6fgVJqLWhCLDs9tZDH722Qv4I-J8WcUwIGzuao6heTQUnzuiDhxQb-~szjlBFN0aBrngQvWDapaUxw9k4vGaEc18Vr0phIIHWMAJLYJj0kaQUsw1FjHcsd3nzyjR~uZU1c6f6UwslQ1K88eo~gXV7wkYPWAojR92DE3CRITSV-YAAEmJMg7GM9LOOB8vAgjyu4mi2tbWMmsf2HDmtP3swU1CMPPdKB8MDOhhtO3Jy8n8WtWbS5MFWJLspkVRkJNL7lM8f3NHipPl7stjL6CHixlU6f4ffLHL-1CpmSvp1zBsAG0r9dSNAHwDKzi2YyRZLWU5A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028928&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">J0112\u22121650 <em>gri</em> stacked models from single-epoch images. (a) Data, (b) three-PSF model subtracting the two blue PSFs, (c) three-PSF model subtracting all PSFs, which clearly shows an extended component in the residuals, (d) three-PSF and galaxy model subtracting the three PSFs, and (e) three-PSF and galaxy model subtracting all components. The white scale bar is 2 arcsec.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028929 id=\"203028929\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4-3>3.4.3 DESJ0229+0320</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system consists of two quasars at a redshift of 1.43, separated by 2.13 arcsec. The spectra are similar, and the multiband multi-epoch modelling (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>) shows similar long-term variability. Furthermore, the apparent brightnesses of these quasars (<em>Gaia</em> magnitudes of 18.15 and 18.79) place them at the bright end of the luminosity function for quasars. These characteristics are all in accordance with strong gravitational lensing \u2013 similar variations, similar spectra, and large apparent brightness due to magnification \u2013 however no lensing galaxy is seen in the deep DES images. To investigate how faint a lens galaxy can be for such a system, we find the <em>i</em>-band magnitudes of a subset of the Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) mocks, namely those with similar redshift sources (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.43\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2) and similar image separations of 2.13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2 arcsec. Of the 192 systems satisfying these criteria, the faintest lensing-galaxy magnitude is 20.8 (<em>z</em> \u223c 0.9; expected once in 100\u2009000\u2009deg<sup>2</sup> of sky). This magnitude is reached in a single-epoch image (for an S/N ratio of 10 for an isolated point source, Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>); however, if it lies close to one of the quasar images, or is particularly extended, then it might not be apparent after PSF subtraction. However, modelling 0.5\u2009arcsec-seeing archival Hyper Suprime Cam <em>z</em>-band data of the system also reveals no evidence of a lensing galaxy (Aihara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Furthermore, the ratio of the spectra in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> shows that the shapes of the Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> lines are different. We believe this is a binary quasar, but high-resolution imaging is required to fully rule out the lensing hypothesis.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028931 id=\"203028931\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4-4>3.4.4 DESJ0246\u22121845</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The resolved NTT spectra for this double show very similar <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.86 quasars. Follow-up NIRC2 data (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) reveal a lensing galaxy verifying the lensing hypothesis. We note that this system was also discovered independently by Krone-Martins et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028933 id=\"203028933\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4-5>3.4.5 DESJ0340\u2212545</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system was found through a <em>Gaia</em> and <em>WISE</em> selection following Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1.1</a>. A slit positioned at 27 degrees East of North confirms two quasar images separated by 6.8 arcsec, each at <em>z</em>\u00a0=1.68 (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). NIRC2 imaging of the system clearly shows three lensing galaxies, two quasar images, and one further object, north of G1 (as labelled in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). Overlaying the <em>Gaia</em> detections for the system on the NIRC2 data reveals that this further object is exactly centred on a <em>Gaia</em> optical detection, and the DES colour image reveals a blue object blended with G1. We investigate whether this object could be the third image of the system, as these faint central images are often observed in lenses with multiple galaxies, resulting in an image slightly offset from one of the lensing-galaxy centres, for example, PSJ0630\u22121201 (Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). To investigate whether C is another quasar image, we create lens models based only on the confirmed quasar images, and see whether the best-fitting lens models naturally predict another image near C. However, we are severely underconstrained given the complex mass distribution of the galaxy group and only two quasar positions and their, often untrustworthy, flux ratio. Given that our model will require a source position, we are left with only 3 degrees of freedom for our lens model. We choose to model the mass contributions of the three galaxies, G1, G2, and G3, set as SIEs, with their flattening parameters set to those of the light (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), and pinned to the measured light positions. Their Einstein radii are all modelled by 1 parameter, <em>b</em>, assuming a constant mass-to-light ratio amongst the galaxies, i.e. using the galaxy flux ratios to set the Einstein radii ratios (<em>L</em>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0<em>M</em>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0<em>b</em><sup>0.5</sup>). We also choose to include an external shear so we have no degrees of freedom remaining, and expect a good fit to have \u03c7<sup>2</sup> \u2248 0. This model reproduces the two bright confirmed quasar images and their flux ratio well. It also predicts a third image 0.22 arcsec away from the postulated image C, and with a flux 15\u00a0per\u2009cent that of A, while C has a measured flux of 10\u00a0per\u2009cent of A. This prediction is enough for us to consider C as a third quasar image without its spectroscopic confirmation. Further evidence for C being a quasar image comes from the remarkably similar flux ratios of the point sources in <em>Gaia</em> and in the NIRC2\u00a0<em>K</em>-band data (as given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), suggesting they have similar spectral energy distributions (SEDs). We can use the three extra constraints this image provides to consider more complex lens models. Considering the same model as before, but now including C as a required quasar image to be reproduced, produces a poor best fit with \u03c7<sup>2</sup> =\u00a0676, given 3 degrees of freedom. We consider two further lens models. First, we allow the mass-to-light ratio to vary between the lensing galaxies, i.e. fit for the Einstein radius of each galaxy. This results in a good fit to the astrometry, but image A is predicted to be about as bright as B, while it is in fact measured to be 2.7\u00a0times brighter. This model might describe the system well, considering there could be large variability over the time delay, so later DES and LSST observations will help exclude this possible model. Our final model fixes the Einstein radii as in our initial models, but now includes an SIS, representing a dark matter halo shared by the lensing galaxies. Its best-fitting position is \u0394<em>x</em>, \u0394<em>y</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.75, 0.60 arcsec from A (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblB1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblB1\" data-open=\"tblB1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>), and the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> for this model is 0.43, given 0 degrees of freedom. These mass models are summarised in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Since the true mass distribution within this group is likely very complicated, these models should only serve as a discussion of the possible probes this system could offer, in particular if deeper high-resolution imaging is pursued to reveal the multiply imaged host-galaxy arcs. The DES images show \u223c15 galaxies within and surrounding the system. Their colours are similar and the internal DES photometric redshift analysis places them all at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02 (Hoyle et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"203028935\" scrollto-destination=\"203028935\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" (1.00)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G1\u00a0</td><td>0.54\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01\u00a0</td><td>150\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>1.00 (\u2013)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G2\u00a0</td><td>0.92\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>96\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07\u00a0</td><td>0.95 \u03b8<sub>\u03b3</sub>, <em>XY<sub>HALO</sub>, b<sub>HALO</sub></em>\u00a0</td><td>0.01, 0.42\u00a0</td><td>0.43\u00a0</td><td>11.6\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203028936\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">DESJ0340\u22122545 has a 15 mJy detection by the VLA Sky Survey (VLASS) at 3\u00a0GHz (Lacy\u00a0&amp; VLASS Survey Team <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and a 2.6 mJy detection in NVSS at 1.4GHz (Condon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>). Given the 2.5 arcsec resolution of VLASS, and the large separation of this system, we are able to determine whether the radio emission is due to the quasar images. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> shows the VLASS 3GHz cut-out with <em>Gaia</em> detections overlaid. The emission is consistent with coming from one or two of the lensing galaxies, G2 and G3 as labelled in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"203028938\" scrollto-destination=\"203028938\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=1vgNiSbCouOexMY3Xi88dhJooIDJ-VloSIqDclub78PxK1I~daoeK18Ns7PYW0FGcC7Le7BOJX5P-V~U1vGyXBURPHMJCoWz6p4DvsN1PeZQaZ96wgd06qVmVf~KelnziAbfmV0zdcHAES91PieUX8O5na8-APHAWGszFRf01Wv27g0P4YU81xyOxWeatsVKW1QAifNnLVnkJyWl000ZRoUbjE3bc1~dXPHMf4sWHywu4BDN4YFESiNikjCianuHQvluWqUyET9Q5fSTresKePSy2S1YkewrBML8-W4LuudueNM~1tamdGmix~204uQFoQpSOKgosVG2kZPFB~OhNw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"VLASS 3GHz image of J0340\u22122545 with quasar and galaxy positions overlaid, as measured from the NIRC2 data and shifted to the Gaia DR2 frame. North is up, East is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028938/staa652fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028938\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=Q-o1equuozHF9~eWLFki8d-qo1euLMUhDNTqWakB2MAb~qx62j9zLy~CMPX03vBYCf-WKs5vJM-C1gp~coKivtrXAEQK3VCmtRGjmp49~wX7pV~XAlYGjQ8vyzZrqMxsCsoEzUHC6rLxN3uU8TFTayTRYGxQ4oFcPr21JqlBPLLq0xHfbYXT3cTxMCO1dpRlp-XQFyoxi4uryRe~yGEPQhFZJFxflvhGE8oOYI9JsUN~h26gXA~rzpVg2SYUW4DZIWUd~w4-WzFyU~7UlBMHOzXzUspoxkhsplfPw5fGpYcGbDMAwJmpa3J1eOGqaf4RxAE9lWkTfM8Ix73soPjyJQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028938&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">VLASS 3GHz image of J0340\u22122545 with quasar and galaxy positions overlaid, as measured from the NIRC2 data and shifted to the <em>Gaia</em> DR2 frame. North is up, East is left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=1vgNiSbCouOexMY3Xi88dhJooIDJ-VloSIqDclub78PxK1I~daoeK18Ns7PYW0FGcC7Le7BOJX5P-V~U1vGyXBURPHMJCoWz6p4DvsN1PeZQaZ96wgd06qVmVf~KelnziAbfmV0zdcHAES91PieUX8O5na8-APHAWGszFRf01Wv27g0P4YU81xyOxWeatsVKW1QAifNnLVnkJyWl000ZRoUbjE3bc1~dXPHMf4sWHywu4BDN4YFESiNikjCianuHQvluWqUyET9Q5fSTresKePSy2S1YkewrBML8-W4LuudueNM~1tamdGmix~204uQFoQpSOKgosVG2kZPFB~OhNw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"VLASS 3GHz image of J0340\u22122545 with quasar and galaxy positions overlaid, as measured from the NIRC2 data and shifted to the Gaia DR2 frame. North is up, East is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028938/staa652fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028938\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=Q-o1equuozHF9~eWLFki8d-qo1euLMUhDNTqWakB2MAb~qx62j9zLy~CMPX03vBYCf-WKs5vJM-C1gp~coKivtrXAEQK3VCmtRGjmp49~wX7pV~XAlYGjQ8vyzZrqMxsCsoEzUHC6rLxN3uU8TFTayTRYGxQ4oFcPr21JqlBPLLq0xHfbYXT3cTxMCO1dpRlp-XQFyoxi4uryRe~yGEPQhFZJFxflvhGE8oOYI9JsUN~h26gXA~rzpVg2SYUW4DZIWUd~w4-WzFyU~7UlBMHOzXzUspoxkhsplfPw5fGpYcGbDMAwJmpa3J1eOGqaf4RxAE9lWkTfM8Ix73soPjyJQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028938&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">VLASS 3GHz image of J0340\u22122545 with quasar and galaxy positions overlaid, as measured from the NIRC2 data and shifted to the <em>Gaia</em> DR2 frame. North is up, East is left.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028939 id=\"203028939\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4-6>3.4.6 DESJ0407\u22121931</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The fainter image of this double is significantly blended with the lensing galaxy, but it is clearly detected in the DES stacked data, and the SOAR imaging. Resolved spectra also show identical emission lines of a quasar at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.26. By subtracting off the scaled NTT spectrum of A from B, we are able to see clear signs of the lensing galaxy absorption lines at <em>z</em>\u00a0=0.288 as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>. The stacked modelled residuals show an excess to the East and West of the brighter image, potentially caused by the lensed host galaxy.</p>                        <a id=\"203028941\" scrollto-destination=\"203028941\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=YW5m5MSG7kKZezoHvbqGppr5XahTNeXk9WnO6AVYVqEolAm~8AWgFaitxW5UITMVqyRpR7oFXl9e2CROLKeoZyJO6hbistI5FiN-FY~rRaYhIg~CRKsnlMRYNk88xW1n4CQET7WvjKRevMj0-rbYihlh3U6GWsjoPxQav~-63fnlZLie23BQVEOp971Vbms7t~Dl5MI3tGLuvlPuD7PdPdGBLMjHDn~quEp3YC8SqYC~3eLIOyb04Dpehs7r~f~9lTLpglBfhcKbpTQqJs5BOuNn6b5k5gEcSDwTOex1pNRoy5rhgCLDrd5iEowvCbFG1PlRPZv3Ni27HlmIQoI7NA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"NTT spectrum of the lensing galaxy of DESJ0407\u22121931, created by subtracting a scaled spectrum of image A from the B\u00a0+\u00a0G blended spectrum. A high signal-to-noise spectrum from SDSS of a galaxy at z\u00a0= 0.288 is plotted for comparison, highlighting the Ca H, K, and Mg lines at 5070, 5115, and 6670\u2009\u00c5, respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028941/staa652fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028941\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=2CmYBdlcBnP8SZ38sYMk58pXgIMoM7RWzi2H0hXX~4oQ6ShNlukdMtYhwk4fd04a0TSDuM3W2y2sXIU~HL3A23BuTwHexPEnefmBjS-6Sv90jbPvSr8nxszZ1wQF0wSgHTeQ4n8QnP7cPaWnqHf8vlsXMBfIwmjMd1or~TdPtuMz3X1P03k5lu~yeiAr0WbwaBCUSXREPnHmTQM2ol7zIwYHLRUhLJWpGJfhBZIoyfXms5d-1WoVMGW6iTbKhKeeQmPqsDyYL3BDN7YtqPm5J~jYLNOLi5tLmBWZAuC6cD5wICvZo~OGiT48I6QBwkFkNuL1lsFt~Qj7FtqLUw9J~Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028941&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">NTT spectrum of the lensing galaxy of DESJ0407\u22121931, created by subtracting a scaled spectrum of image A from the B\u00a0+\u00a0G blended spectrum. A high signal-to-noise spectrum from SDSS of a galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.288 is plotted for comparison, highlighting the Ca H, K, and Mg lines at 5070, 5115, and 6670\u2009\u00c5, respectively.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=YW5m5MSG7kKZezoHvbqGppr5XahTNeXk9WnO6AVYVqEolAm~8AWgFaitxW5UITMVqyRpR7oFXl9e2CROLKeoZyJO6hbistI5FiN-FY~rRaYhIg~CRKsnlMRYNk88xW1n4CQET7WvjKRevMj0-rbYihlh3U6GWsjoPxQav~-63fnlZLie23BQVEOp971Vbms7t~Dl5MI3tGLuvlPuD7PdPdGBLMjHDn~quEp3YC8SqYC~3eLIOyb04Dpehs7r~f~9lTLpglBfhcKbpTQqJs5BOuNn6b5k5gEcSDwTOex1pNRoy5rhgCLDrd5iEowvCbFG1PlRPZv3Ni27HlmIQoI7NA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"NTT spectrum of the lensing galaxy of DESJ0407\u22121931, created by subtracting a scaled spectrum of image A from the B\u00a0+\u00a0G blended spectrum. A high signal-to-noise spectrum from SDSS of a galaxy at z\u00a0= 0.288 is plotted for comparison, highlighting the Ca H, K, and Mg lines at 5070, 5115, and 6670\u2009\u00c5, respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028941/staa652fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028941\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=2CmYBdlcBnP8SZ38sYMk58pXgIMoM7RWzi2H0hXX~4oQ6ShNlukdMtYhwk4fd04a0TSDuM3W2y2sXIU~HL3A23BuTwHexPEnefmBjS-6Sv90jbPvSr8nxszZ1wQF0wSgHTeQ4n8QnP7cPaWnqHf8vlsXMBfIwmjMd1or~TdPtuMz3X1P03k5lu~yeiAr0WbwaBCUSXREPnHmTQM2ol7zIwYHLRUhLJWpGJfhBZIoyfXms5d-1WoVMGW6iTbKhKeeQmPqsDyYL3BDN7YtqPm5J~jYLNOLi5tLmBWZAuC6cD5wICvZo~OGiT48I6QBwkFkNuL1lsFt~Qj7FtqLUw9J~Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028941&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">NTT spectrum of the lensing galaxy of DESJ0407\u22121931, created by subtracting a scaled spectrum of image A from the B\u00a0+\u00a0G blended spectrum. A high signal-to-noise spectrum from SDSS of a galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.288 is plotted for comparison, highlighting the Ca H, K, and Mg lines at 5070, 5115, and 6670\u2009\u00c5, respectively.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028942 id=\"203028942\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4-7>3.4.7 DESJ0508\u22122748</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The NTT and ESI spectra for this object both show a blended <em>z</em>\u00a0=1.14 quasar without any other obvious features. NIRC2 data reveals two point sources, separated by 0.65 arcsec, with no obvious lensing galaxy after PSF subtraction. We leave this object as inconclusive since the spectra are not resolved and there are no other indicators as to its nature (e.g. high proper motion <em>Gaia</em> detection, additional spectral features, or detection of a single quasar host galaxy).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028944 id=\"203028944\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4-8>3.4.8 DESJ2349\u22124518</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system is a high-flux-ratio double (7.5 to 1), with a Sydney University Molonglo Sky Survey detection of 13.6 mJy at 843\u00a0MHz (Mauch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), with a source redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.90. This lens system lacks SOAR or NIRC2 data, so we show DES <em>gri</em> colour images with the brighter PSF and both PSFs subtracted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>. This system is the only double with a non-zero \u03c7<sup>2</sup> for the single SIE fit. The largest contribution to the residuals is from the observed flux ratio being higher than the model predicts. This is most likely explained by microlensing, variability, or attenuation of the fainter image due to the lensing galaxy.</p>                        <a id=\"203028946\" scrollto-destination=\"203028946\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=ER2wV~g5BgkMLLe-5ymioelCtBYQfZPcr7naPGnHNPIbO5XN953TJnTvyyA4f2DOkFv3EjAIijKFBvM5urZd69cVEit5s~NidzH9fQulft0FB-BkR23yvUfShomTbYsURuqYoceA52-B7JgPPCLFyMpuclVe2MirrK16jflVgLsJuo60hoap9xXIehum80-c9mu1qqanEd48KmkXSXzrBNWHc4ivtN~Am9ybF0cdEy3Fxfo5OnasyAWariBkwamFgmd6zM4sn1qLK3cUcfBc4npMHN0UdfiODoLsRqXC~2LaKwXeRUQ8Eblzj7NsO~vRppNtQkN5orphS3ISOs3FHA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES gri stacked model for DESJ2349\u22124518: (a) data, (b) subtraction of image A and lensing galaxy, (c) subtraction of both quasar images, and (d) subtraction of all components. The white scale bar is 2 arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028946/staa652fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028946\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=CHXUK618NeL-iDi7Zs43yiWT5OhL~LnsyQHe8Dfw9YAT0LLJ85hUGgXDcZ6ucvVcMNegxeeppXL35OrUdVvOob5I7C57u4af3OrK9vCGk7icKY6UH3-DJ7p3PrY3wUX1PS6nGqCZQBDgig6W6Z2UOfzT-cVqRy3XNXdaRCpDmcRwiBbtApuczQr0Gl4X9Y09HLmrK5-7wd7qh8uqWdKKR1IziHwzYBwp5YNX7ujt4vVWcs3fcz38hc8HWBrBSRZ5JhZtPQpKpkL6q37QRoZQfbrknIYlQPGOQopSV-Y1oK98Zk8Kaqp2tozP-8xCFZSgdCc4srL3Vj6Jqy5QsxQGWQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028946&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES <em>gri</em> stacked model for DESJ2349\u22124518: (a) data, (b) subtraction of image A and lensing galaxy, (c) subtraction of both quasar images, and (d) subtraction of all components. The white scale bar is 2 arcsec.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=ER2wV~g5BgkMLLe-5ymioelCtBYQfZPcr7naPGnHNPIbO5XN953TJnTvyyA4f2DOkFv3EjAIijKFBvM5urZd69cVEit5s~NidzH9fQulft0FB-BkR23yvUfShomTbYsURuqYoceA52-B7JgPPCLFyMpuclVe2MirrK16jflVgLsJuo60hoap9xXIehum80-c9mu1qqanEd48KmkXSXzrBNWHc4ivtN~Am9ybF0cdEy3Fxfo5OnasyAWariBkwamFgmd6zM4sn1qLK3cUcfBc4npMHN0UdfiODoLsRqXC~2LaKwXeRUQ8Eblzj7NsO~vRppNtQkN5orphS3ISOs3FHA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES gri stacked model for DESJ2349\u22124518: (a) data, (b) subtraction of image A and lensing galaxy, (c) subtraction of both quasar images, and (d) subtraction of all components. The white scale bar is 2 arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028946/staa652fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028946\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=CHXUK618NeL-iDi7Zs43yiWT5OhL~LnsyQHe8Dfw9YAT0LLJ85hUGgXDcZ6ucvVcMNegxeeppXL35OrUdVvOob5I7C57u4af3OrK9vCGk7icKY6UH3-DJ7p3PrY3wUX1PS6nGqCZQBDgig6W6Z2UOfzT-cVqRy3XNXdaRCpDmcRwiBbtApuczQr0Gl4X9Y09HLmrK5-7wd7qh8uqWdKKR1IziHwzYBwp5YNX7ujt4vVWcs3fcz38hc8HWBrBSRZ5JhZtPQpKpkL6q37QRoZQfbrknIYlQPGOQopSV-Y1oK98Zk8Kaqp2tozP-8xCFZSgdCc4srL3Vj6Jqy5QsxQGWQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028946&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES <em>gri</em> stacked model for DESJ2349\u22124518: (a) data, (b) subtraction of image A and lensing galaxy, (c) subtraction of both quasar images, and (d) subtraction of all components. The white scale bar is 2 arcsec.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028947 id=\"203028947\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-5>3.5 Nearly identical quasar pairs</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, we present crude estimates for how faint a possible lensing galaxy can be for each of the 10 nearly identical quasar pairs (NIQs). The method is based only on separation and source redshift, following the prescription explained in Treu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), using the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenspop</span> package (Collett <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). We note that the DES median coadded catalogue depths for a 1.95\u2009arcsec diameter aperture at S/N =\u00a010 in the <em>griz</em> bands are 24.3, 24.1, 23.4, and 22.7\u2009mag, respectively (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). However, we cannot conclusively rule out the existence of lensing galaxies since they are extended (and hence are more difficult to detect) and our PSF subtraction may fit part of this lensing galaxy flux, especially if one image lies close to the lens and/or the systems have small angular separations.</p>                        <a id=\"203028949\" scrollto-destination=\"203028949\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl6\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Estimates of the faintest magnitudes of possible lenses in <em>griz</em> for the NIQs, based on image separation and source redshift.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394\u03b8 (\u2009arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>g</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>i</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>DESJ0027+0232\u00a0</td><td>2.72\u00a0</td><td>2.02\u00a0</td><td>26.3\u00a0</td><td>24.0\u00a0</td><td>22.2\u00a0</td><td>20.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ0101\u22124943\u00a0</td><td>4.02\u00a0</td><td>2.10\u00a0</td><td>25.5\u00a0</td><td>22.7\u00a0</td><td>21.4\u00a0</td><td>20.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ0118\u22120104\u00a0</td><td>1.74\u00a0</td><td>0.74\u00a0</td><td>22.9\u00a0</td><td>21.0\u00a0</td><td>19.9\u00a0</td><td>19.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ0118\u22123115\u00a0</td><td>1.00\u00a0</td><td>1.74\u00a0</td><td>28.1\u00a0</td><td>25.3\u00a0</td><td>24.0\u00a0</td><td>22.7\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ0122+0358\u00a0</td><td>1.71\u00a0</td><td>1.69\u00a0</td><td>26.9\u00a0</td><td>24.0\u00a0</td><td>22.8\u00a0</td><td>21.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ0229+0320\u00a0</td><td>2.08\u00a0</td><td>1.43\u00a0</td><td>25.8\u00a0</td><td>23.0\u00a0</td><td>21.7\u00a0</td><td>20.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ0254-2243\u00a0</td><td>2.32\u00a0</td><td>2.04\u00a0</td><td>26.7\u00a0</td><td>24.4\u00a0</td><td>22.6\u00a0</td><td>21.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ0313\u22122546\u00a0</td><td>2.20\u00a0</td><td>1.96\u00a0</td><td>26.7\u00a0</td><td>24.3\u00a0</td><td>22.6\u00a0</td><td>21.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ0443\u22122403\u00a0</td><td>1.85\u00a0</td><td>1.78\u00a0</td><td>26.9\u00a0</td><td>24.1\u00a0</td><td>22.8\u00a0</td><td>21.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ2215\u22125204\u00a0</td><td>2.74\u00a0</td><td>2.35\u00a0</td><td>26.5\u00a0</td><td>25.0\u00a0</td><td>22.8\u00a0</td><td>21.3\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394\u03b8 (\u2009arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Estimates of the faintest magnitudes of possible lenses in <em>griz</em> for the NIQs, based on image separation and source class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203028949\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203028950 id=\"203028950\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 VARIABILITY MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A central aspect of the DES is its repeated observations of a large area of sky over 5\u00a0yr. This allows us to extract variability information in the <em>grizY</em> bandpasses (with central wavelengths 4827, 6432, 7827, 9179, 9900\u2009\u00c5, respectively), as explored for efficient quasar detection in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.3</a> (Flaugher et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Extracting variability information for the multiple components of nearby blends of objects offers a promising way to (i) remove quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star systems from future follow-up of potential doubly imaged quasars (Kochanek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006a</a>), (ii) prioritize possible lenses amongst nearly identical quasar pairs by looking for similar variability, as has been done with targeted repeat observations of SDSS candidates (Sergeyev et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Shalyapin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and (iii) reduce contamination by quasar pairs through searching for time delays (Pindor <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). For lensed quasars in high-cadence fields, constraints can be placed on the time delays (Kostrzewa-Rutkowska et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). However, applying variability analysis on pipeline magnitudes of close-separation pairs will lead to spurious results due to flux-sharing (Tewes, Courbin\u00a0&amp; Meylan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and variable seeing, and excludes applicability to all cases of blended sources that are not segmented by the source extraction software.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This problem has been well-explored by teams dedicated to lensed quasar monitoring for extraction of light curves and hence time delays. In particular, photometry has been extracted through fitting multiple PSFs (e.g. Goicoechea\u00a0&amp; Shalyapin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Koptelova et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), fitting multiple PSFs and parametric galaxy components (e.g. Kochanek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>; Hainline et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Shalyapin\u00a0&amp; Goicoechea <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), difference imaging (e.g. Fohlmeister et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Giannini et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), aperture photometry for wide-separation systems (e.g. Ovaldsen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Dahle et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and non-parametric deconvolutional techniques (e.g. Burud et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Vuissoz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028953 id=\"203028953\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 A photometry pipeline for lensed quasars</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that understanding the PSF is vital for deriving reliable photometry from each epoch. Tests using PSFEx (Bertin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) reconstructions do not fit the PSFs of our systems precisely enough, and there is no knowledge of the uncertainty on the PSF model over which to marginalize. Using nearby stars or stacks of nearby stars as the PSF is also often inconsistent with the PSF of the system, perhaps due to spatial variations, colour mismatches, or brightness mismatches between the system PSF and the star PSFs, which can exhibit different shapes due to flux-dependent charge interactions (i.e. the brighter-fatter effect; Gruen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Walter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). We therefore opt for an initial PSF fit by a Moffat profile to a nearby star, but we later allow the data from each epoch to fit this profile, and marginalize over the Moffat parameters. For systems with bright point sources (<em>Gaia G</em> &lt; 18), this profile often fails to describe the PSF to the noise as expected, and we remove the relevant frames from our analysis. For the remaining frames of these bright systems, the photometric uncertainty is often &lt;0.01 mag, and so only a few frames are needed to statistically verify variability. Poor Moffat fits are uncommon for the fainter systems, for which more frames are required for a robust detection of variability given the increased photometric uncertainties on fainter point sources.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the following, we use all single-epoch images with DES \u2018Final Cut\u2019 processing from the first 4 yr of DES (Morganson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The steps of the modelling pipeline are as follows:</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">40\u00a0\u00d7\u00a040\u00a0pixel cut-outs of all single-epoch images centred on the relevant system are inspected, and any showing artefacts/cosmic rays or significantly poor seeing (over 2 arcsec FWHM based on the FITS header information), are excluded from the modelling.</p></li><li><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To determine the zero-point in each band, stellar objects on the same CCD are found by plotting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$MAG\\_AUTO-MAG\\_PSF$|</span> versus <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$MAG\\_AUTO$|</span> (as derived from <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span>, Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>), fitting a line to the stellar locus, and selecting all objects within 0.05 mag of this line and with catalogued magnitudes between 15.5 and 19. The sky background is estimated from a fit to the histogram of pixels between 5 and 25 arcsec around each star, after a 5\u03c3 clip. The background level is determined through the Bayesian model of Bijaoui (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>), however we also include some fraction of empty sky pixels in this model. Following the notation of Bijaoui (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>), the (unnormalized) probability distribution of true sky flux (<em>i</em>) values is <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray}\r\np \\left(i \\right)=\\kappa \\delta \\left(i \\right) \\ \\ \\ \\textrm{if} \\ \\ \\ i=0,\\ \\ \\ p \\left(i \\right)=\\frac{1}{a}\\mathrm{e}^{-i/a} \\ \\ \\ \\textrm{if} \\ \\ \\ i\\gt 0 ,\r\n\\end{eqnarray}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>where \u03ba describes the contribution from empty sky pixels relative to pixels from faint objects, and the wings of PSFs and galaxies. Given a sky background, <em>s</em>, and Gaussian noise, \u03c3, the unnormalized observed flux (<em>I</em>) distribution is <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray}\r\np \\left(I \\right) &amp;\\propto &amp;\\frac{\\kappa }{2 \\pi {\\sigma }^{2}} \\textrm{exp}\\left(-\\frac{{\\left(I-s \\right)}^{2}}{2{\\sigma }^2}\\right) \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp; +\\frac{1}{a}\\textrm{exp}\\left(\\frac{{\\sigma }^2}{2{a}^2}\\right)\\textrm{exp}\\left(-\\frac{\\left(I-s\\right)}{a}\\right) {\\textrm{erf}}_{c}\\left(\\frac{\\sigma }{a}-\\frac{\\left(I-s\\right)}{\\sigma }\\right). \\\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The parameter space is explored using <span class=\"small-caps\">emcee</span> (Foreman-Mackey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), so a true sky background and its uncertainty are inferred. The flux for each star is then the sum of the background-subtracted 5.4 arcsec (20\u00a0pixel) circular aperture, and the flux uncertainty includes Poisson noise, sky-background noise, and uncertainty in the subtracted background value. Finally we include a magnitude uncertainty of 0.003 in quadrature with the photometric uncertainty to account for possible systematic biases in bright stars, following Burke et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">In each band, we simultaneously fit the zero-points of all frames in that band. Since our goal is to measure variability, we can set one frame\u2019s zero-point to that of the average value derived from the calibration stars\u2019 catalogued magnitudes (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). For any combination of zero-points, each calibration star\u2019s best-fitting magnitude is found by minimizing the \u03c7<sup>2</sup>. Therefore, for <em>N</em> epochs in a given band, we perform an optimization procedure to infer <em>N</em> \u2212 1 zero-points. Any stars with reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> above 100 are removed and the optimization is repeated. This procedure is then iterated, removing stars with reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> above 50, 25, 10, 6, and 4. This preferentially removes the fainter stars in the sample, perhaps due to intrinsic variability, or because their photometry is more sensitive to seeing variations and contamination by nearby objects. Typically \u223c80\u00a0per\u2009cent of stars are retained after these iterations, and the zero-points are then sampled with <span class=\"small-caps\">emcee</span>. Uncertainties on these zero-points are \u223c0.001\u20130.003 mag.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The relative differences between these zero-points are consistent with the relative differences of DES pipeline zero-points (Burke et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) to &lt;0.01 mag. However, the absolute magnitudes can differ by up to 0.02 mag. This is expected since we attempted no aperture corrections on the star fluxes. Instead, we will apply the same 5.4 arcsec apertures on our model PSF components, since we only want to constrain relative fluxes.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">After fitting a nearby point source with a Moffat profile, the best seeing frame in each band is fit simultaneously with a combination of point sources and Sersic profiles. Astrometric registrations between the <em>g</em> and <em>rizY</em> bands are also modelled. Once the chains have converged, the best-fitting model is used to set the alignment of all other frames (again with a nearby star fit for the frame\u2019s Moffat parameters), and finally the PSF and galaxy parameters are constrained from all frames simultaneously. These new best-fitting parameters are used to constrain the best-fitting Moffat profiles and alignment on each frame individually, and all frames are again modelled simultaneously. Any poor-fitting frames are removed after visual inspection, and the Moffat fits and simultaneous-frame fits are repeated. The convergence of each chain is visually checked at each stage. This process provides a burnt-in chain of PSF positions and galaxy parameters.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">For 50 samples of this model chain, the model PSF fluxes are determined in each frame through the same apertures as were applied to the zero-point calibration stars (5.4 arcsec circular apertures). However, since the Moffat parameters can affect these fluxes by \u223c1\u00a0per\u2009cent, we marginalize over all Moffat parameters and alignment offsets, by sampling these parameters at each step of the model chain. The concatenated chain of fluxes for PSFs and galaxies (the sum of the brightest 500 unconvolved pixels), provides the magnitudes and their uncertainties at each epoch. We add an ad hoc uncertainty of 0.005 mag in quadrature with the sampled uncertainty to account for any remaining systematics (poor centring of calibration stars within their apertures, lack of modelling of host galaxies, etc.), which brings the reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> for non-variable objects to unity.</p></li></ul>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028957 id=\"203028957\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Variability of DES systems</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028958 id=\"203028958\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-1>4.2.1 Removing stellar contaminants</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The most common contaminant in lens searches is quasars projected close to blue stars, mimicking doubly imaged quasars. While their optical colours can be similar, their SEDs vary towards redder wavelengths, as exploited by the modelling of un<em>WISE</em> pixels using <em>Gaia</em> positions to remove such systems from lens searches (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). However, this modelling can only be applied to brighter systems with <em>Gaia</em> detections and high signal-to-noise detections in <em>WISE</em>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We investigate how variability information can be used to further remove contaminant systems including stars. We take a sample of 16 spectroscopically confirmed quasar and star pairs (appendix B, Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and derive their light curves following Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>. We also repeat the analysis for all known lensed quasars within the DES footprint.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> Example light curves with representative sampling and photometric uncertainties are shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a> for a quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star system and lensed quasar, respectively. For our analysis we only retain systems with more than three photometric points over at least two observing seasons in at least three bands. To measure the variability of components in these systems, we take the reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> after fitting all photometry to the same magnitude. We expect values around 1 for non-variable components, but we also note that for magnitudes at the limiting single-epoch magnitude for the survey, the photometric errors naturally limit our detection of variability. Furthermore, there exist covariances between the photometric data points since the zero-points were fit simultaneously, however we can safely neglect these since the zero-points are much more well determined than the relative photometry.</p>                        <a id=\"203028961\" scrollto-destination=\"203028961\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=WpQfHB-Xj9~nzJxiCRnhuZ2b-D0g44hFebKUad8A~oY-POfmwFvtvUjVSZWQlsaxjFeXUabtJ3LE3bBnXLVwH0FgcIYnrF8Hp8QmYxee82ml6QJ6yTR2msXDQ5FfhVGODLuHYpn8jBrpKiuDMZb0HSh1lvkzQbCst3mrf9L7EX7rddjZnSM7dZ7FmnR~5yrGKi9mAHDvgk2etm1XZgMydOvCtr9FJ72FSONnrHOUnznx4tzyUu75LR2099H8CD~LAw4hh2f-k8jurIBbtDdEgNFsH0fkiiJp2-RHY-t05OUH4GVwJyq~LzTQfrJMyDbZNqGdq82~s7xvDX5JeZMu5g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES z-band light curves for the projected star and quasar system DESJ0201\u22122043, clearly showing variability in the quasar component. Such light curves rely only on DES data, and as such are a useful way to remove contaminant systems from spectroscopic follow-up.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"203028962\"
