class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=iwp3qpB8wNzHI9rO7qcgSagktNVeHCDlX5i6vOOQBRHjn4ByDgaWCMMPEMOjsVM2e3fnArpqgY1XMjcOKSNQ7Ow3L1gCdO0axzaJ4UmtQxX0jco7oiYekWGpr6CtM3p62IS1xN8eTBEZxXSHezkERGkxF2~d4yxEAQndc2yVDMxY0TXirtflIO2qeAORtjhPavlbLNDCPmPUZgnCCOJJlIUgffmeRde~g8JJhyNNCrL8VvZsQ5QQ9J6rxZ3getDLCYLW6KWy8Q3RxaxNUZAaIc~3n9jiLsfDazOSMSsAPaCEnTkRIpwFKSiFUjgoW1p7tLthYJdGHKmOluRcke~jLg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES i-band light curves for the lensed quasar system DESJ0150\u22124041, showing similar variations in the quasar images over a long baseline, and a lensing galaxy with consistent photometry.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028962/staa652fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028962\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=lWZYUNDg~st7B66VW0K0gzlih608v5Buv1zYFcWsoKA5d7cXc9DCYy7fAFnNdNirAe~jPi4oUopRDoYxB~mzz80RXDF52KxK-NeVJ4FIeiEcZt158qkIkVx6xFpWGQWrS9654v7mzMlh7aodsMZ1lBm2nDKKwd2V2AvdLFs0VIXeb50or0XDGc6NJg6K31bWb6LbaF7SZS1Uw8SaQ3dVLUWgqhPuaHrN8--A4BbSxdmjYwcabAiWN3QAfZJ27dUiRSJh4bLdikuMWL0AfF9P5rzF-~9N0gouYDHjGRQ82YBpOIxjke27U9XgFDXWY03qgdKhSpQQF6OVB77ed9hQHQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028962&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES <em>i</em>-band light curves for the lensed quasar system DESJ0150\u22124041, showing similar variations in the quasar images over a long baseline, and a lensing galaxy with consistent photometry.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> shows the average reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> across all measured bands for the two most variable point sources in a system, for a sample of 15 quasar and star systems, 16 lensed quasars, and 16 quasar pairs. The quasar-pair sample may contain lensed quasars with faint, yet currently undetected, lensing galaxies, and are discussed further in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2.3</a>. We expect the variability of the less variable object to be a good indicator of whether the system has only quasar components, or a non-variable quasar component. A cut retaining systems with average reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> &gt; 3.16 removes 15 of the 16 stellar contaminant systems, while retaining all lensed quasars. Assuming that we can extend this analysis to all 24 systems we have spectroscopically classified as containing stars with the DES 6 yr data (but are not currently able to, due to lacking the number of good-fitting epochs in at least three bands), we would expect that the suggested cut can remove 22 systems. This would reduce our contaminant systems to 13, composed of 2 systems with stars, and the rest of star-forming galaxies and quasar-galaxy projections (i.e. at different redshifts without strong lensing). Our confirmation rate of lensed quasars and quasar pairs would then increase from 34\u201345\u00a0per\u2009cent to 51\u201370\u00a0per\u2009cent, with the spread due to the inconclusive systems. Further investigation of colour-based variability may allow for separation of variable stars and quasars.</p>                        <a id=\"203028964\" scrollto-destination=\"203028964\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig14.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=e63JYs8jfNOOWkBtyNMaHKmI6zjzCAlI8V6V1XZLQHfOjsskivbLg8N0jc3fBFG7-bgYmKUw71gtmILhUlBGjV8sZYtrlN3Wzr2ACSpB4VnVAO52gr3w2x~fgZcrApSljoSu9d8Br3fo-1DpNRFckiBCHTjwK80c10warchqzpZ-GlwLEI4gE88JbntbXWr1sToZgLkZMZXt6TOYIdr-qhAIfaZVL1qooD1iwRMU~J77T7jpMr6tCvaXXc7mI4i8VXz~aDzyMx4KhsD9HoHJO0GK-N9cGdgOraF7PyqKuZWUoeZVLJuUaqeIpAWTFL9z-v5jyQKpvSPkSgoYTX0BAg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Average reduced \u03c72 over all bands containing three or more epochs of reliable photometry over at least two observing seasons. A cut of average log10\u2009\u03c72 &gt; 0.5 retains all modelled lensed quasars, while removing 94\u00a0per\u2009cent of the contaminant systems containing stars. The more variable component (B) is plotted against the less variable component (A).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig14.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028964/staa652fig14.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig14.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028964\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig14.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=xUEH1k3JyyLgqJBL1QkPSmGOe5mlX-EPtggSBFtpYDO4zoGa8q6~uALDii7VpWB8GDK1jML5q11~gtGuT2lTcqlemPjbGP1MWnh2hCejs5LyYL10gsHZR4kTEv~1WUCDHgfVP8~LeOUp8rGjs9NAXjJ1TnpbMNIZSUVtn48Q2GY41lti1VeQ1tQd8-MFtcpF6qUMbvhiXkkaYaVa8eel9zxMSAkg-xXkcF1muC03aGleTtIGLLtI51RqG4BOvUBuKBMN2PokM5PvN2RMYh7Jy6UwHu4qVOCh4~32-746B221oafrTLzFdxQ0ql8oz8i5YxPkBlYZT9dsW6PEVd9FcQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028964&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig14.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Average reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> over all bands containing three or more epochs of reliable photometry over at least two observing seasons. A cut of average log<sub>10</sub>\u2009\u03c7<sup>2</sup> &gt; 0.5 retains all modelled lensed quasars, while removing 94\u00a0per\u2009cent of the contaminant systems containing stars. The more variable component (<em>B</em>) is plotted against the less variable component (<em>A</em>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig14.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=e63JYs8jfNOOWkBtyNMaHKmI6zjzCAlI8V6V1XZLQHfOjsskivbLg8N0jc3fBFG7-bgYmKUw71gtmILhUlBGjV8sZYtrlN3Wzr2ACSpB4VnVAO52gr3w2x~fgZcrApSljoSu9d8Br3fo-1DpNRFckiBCHTjwK80c10warchqzpZ-GlwLEI4gE88JbntbXWr1sToZgLkZMZXt6TOYIdr-qhAIfaZVL1qooD1iwRMU~J77T7jpMr6tCvaXXc7mI4i8VXz~aDzyMx4KhsD9HoHJO0GK-N9cGdgOraF7PyqKuZWUoeZVLJuUaqeIpAWTFL9z-v5jyQKpvSPkSgoYTX0BAg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Average reduced \u03c72 over all bands containing three or more epochs of reliable photometry over at least two observing seasons. A cut of average log10\u2009\u03c72 &gt; 0.5 retains all modelled lensed quasars, while removing 94\u00a0per\u2009cent of the contaminant systems containing stars. The more variable component (B) is plotted against the less variable component (A).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig14.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028964/staa652fig14.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig14.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028964\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig14.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=xUEH1k3JyyLgqJBL1QkPSmGOe5mlX-EPtggSBFtpYDO4zoGa8q6~uALDii7VpWB8GDK1jML5q11~gtGuT2lTcqlemPjbGP1MWnh2hCejs5LyYL10gsHZR4kTEv~1WUCDHgfVP8~LeOUp8rGjs9NAXjJ1TnpbMNIZSUVtn48Q2GY41lti1VeQ1tQd8-MFtcpF6qUMbvhiXkkaYaVa8eel9zxMSAkg-xXkcF1muC03aGleTtIGLLtI51RqG4BOvUBuKBMN2PokM5PvN2RMYh7Jy6UwHu4qVOCh4~32-746B221oafrTLzFdxQ0ql8oz8i5YxPkBlYZT9dsW6PEVd9FcQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028964&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig14.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Average reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> over all bands containing three or more epochs of reliable photometry over at least two observing seasons. A cut of average log<sub>10</sub>\u2009\u03c7<sup>2</sup> &gt; 0.5 retains all modelled lensed quasars, while removing 94\u00a0per\u2009cent of the contaminant systems containing stars. The more variable component (<em>B</em>) is plotted against the less variable component (<em>A</em>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The top histogram of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> shows the variability measure for the most variable component in each system. For the quasar and star pairs this is always the quasar component, and for the lensed quasars, this is generally the brighter image. The unlensed quasars from the quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star pairs are less variable than their lensed counterparts. This is not due to the former set having fainter apparent magnitudes and hence being less significantly variable through the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> statistic, as both sets have similar distributions of observed brightnesses. It is more likely explained by a combination of three factors: (i) the magnification due to the lensing implies that intrinsic magnitudes of lensed quasars are fainter than the counterparts in the quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star systems, and less luminous quasars are well known to vary more (e.g. Hook et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>; Koz\u0142owski <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Li et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>); (ii) lensed quasars are susceptible to additional extrinsic variations through microlensing; and (iii) our unlensed quasar sample has a lower redshift distribution than the lensed quasars (the unlensed, lensed, and NIQ samples have median redshifts of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.88, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.80, and <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.76, respectively). Given that bluer quasar emission is intrinsically more variable, for a given observed wavelength range, a higher redshift quasar will be more variable. Furthermore, there is a weak trend of increasing variability with increasing redshift at a fixed rest-frame wavelength (Li et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028966 id=\"203028966\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-2>4.2.2 J0235\u22122433</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This doubly imaged lensed quasar was suspected to have an image undergoing a long-term microlensing event due to a large discrepancy between the image flux ratio in the DES and Pan-STARRS data (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The DES light curves corroborate this interpretation. In all bands, image A decreases in brightness by \u223c0.3 mag from Year 2 to Year 4, while image B increases over the first year of this same period by 0.3 mag and drops by 0.6 mag in the following year. The <em>z</em>- and <em>Y</em>-band light curves include an epoch in Year 1, showing the two images are of similar magnitude, while in Year 3 the difference is 0.9 mag. If the time delay were comparable to the baseline of our observations, then this could simply be an effect caused by the images sampling the source quasar at entirely different epochs. However, the source redshift is relatively low (<em>z</em>\u00a0=1.44), the lens galaxy is particularly bright implying a low redshift, and the separation is modest (2.04 arcsec). Simple lens models for such systems are expected to have time delays under 50\u00a0d, much shorter than the 3 yr observation baseline. The <em>Y</em>-band light curves (the band with the longest baseline) are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>, clearly showing that image B has undergone variations inconsistent with that of image A.</p>                        <a id=\"203028968\" scrollto-destination=\"203028968\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig15.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=nBCy22nZChKdmG6zbG9DHaHEBwR-KXedx0mLtSYq~x1ZuoiZ8D2vTnbdBKXWl~4e8UnzOqnSr~ON4leZy8ok8BapZ4AkTLNyvbSst6m22nkvckRMwqnbGk4KFPcy055cHjTLcObNU0nJfBVOT-skJMHGNK8rSHpKelpZI-Rmemn~DkmXoGt-G~9JcQckIKL4BrJR4iesY6Uufy-rLnDkYEnwUFZKSWtHFFmA7c7KA4oG4s~~cPfl31VTkgpfOjg1J8UwYH9cfCt3Dwe6gDUt3dBp0hkIhPK~i~75PkfOE3YG~lmPugjnL9FKcrXrVcDlV5gBzT-X03FpF-jz6eaN~Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES Y-band light curves for the lensed quasar system J0235\u22122433, showing a likely microlensing event in image B over 3\u00a0yr. Similar variations are seen in the other bands, and cannot be explained by the time-delay difference without invoking multiple large variation and short-lived flares in the source quasar.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig15.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028968/staa652fig15.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig15.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028968\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig15.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=ZCJJVY98f0rvMSXAC0tez5-GBmaCItSd46mrzKBeEBwDEDHNhInbxdpZBTUh8m5542C0TIodGSq4TWCzN9RLiQxv8K~Xcw4jSbvMw47acfmVnBQqVaNDKXckQ~PT67d-Vq34Z3-kE-0yLgCguunwJonv2fJPvApKFkChaBPVyxQ8RxZr0MOm1kzam0fctizixzH3IegIFFI1AQRbWkmyHUz6n8q1liUQSkxYVT-xfnJhGasVsL2Jv92t31WA8krcO5CJLeg4sOiZIsKlUodmi2DAt9A34IsiA~4E0Kyil9NgMfur8lz0n5W7uE~9zjTVXTaiD1lZ96HL-AKEUt4VDA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028968&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig15.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES <em>Y</em>-band light curves for the lensed quasar system J0235\u22122433, showing a likely microlensing event in image B over 3\u00a0yr. Similar variations are seen in the other bands, and cannot be explained by the time-delay difference without invoking multiple large variation and short-lived flares in the source quasar.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig15.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=nBCy22nZChKdmG6zbG9DHaHEBwR-KXedx0mLtSYq~x1ZuoiZ8D2vTnbdBKXWl~4e8UnzOqnSr~ON4leZy8ok8BapZ4AkTLNyvbSst6m22nkvckRMwqnbGk4KFPcy055cHjTLcObNU0nJfBVOT-skJMHGNK8rSHpKelpZI-Rmemn~DkmXoGt-G~9JcQckIKL4BrJR4iesY6Uufy-rLnDkYEnwUFZKSWtHFFmA7c7KA4oG4s~~cPfl31VTkgpfOjg1J8UwYH9cfCt3Dwe6gDUt3dBp0hkIhPK~i~75PkfOE3YG~lmPugjnL9FKcrXrVcDlV5gBzT-X03FpF-jz6eaN~Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES Y-band light curves for the lensed quasar system J0235\u22122433, showing a likely microlensing event in image B over 3\u00a0yr. Similar variations are seen in the other bands, and cannot be explained by the time-delay difference without invoking multiple large variation and short-lived flares in the source quasar.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig15.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028968/staa652fig15.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig15.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028968\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig15.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=ZCJJVY98f0rvMSXAC0tez5-GBmaCItSd46mrzKBeEBwDEDHNhInbxdpZBTUh8m5542C0TIodGSq4TWCzN9RLiQxv8K~Xcw4jSbvMw47acfmVnBQqVaNDKXckQ~PT67d-Vq34Z3-kE-0yLgCguunwJonv2fJPvApKFkChaBPVyxQ8RxZr0MOm1kzam0fctizixzH3IegIFFI1AQRbWkmyHUz6n8q1liUQSkxYVT-xfnJhGasVsL2Jv92t31WA8krcO5CJLeg4sOiZIsKlUodmi2DAt9A34IsiA~4E0Kyil9NgMfur8lz0n5W7uE~9zjTVXTaiD1lZ96HL-AKEUt4VDA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028968&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig15.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES <em>Y</em>-band light curves for the lensed quasar system J0235\u22122433, showing a likely microlensing event in image B over 3\u00a0yr. Similar variations are seen in the other bands, and cannot be explained by the time-delay difference without invoking multiple large variation and short-lived flares in the source quasar.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203028969 id=\"203028969\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-3>4.2.3 Nearly identical quasar pairs</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows that the faintest possible lensing galaxies for more than half of our quasar pairs can have <em>i</em>-band magnitudes fainter than 22.4, approximately a magnitude brighter than the DES data release 1 coadd magnitude limit (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$MAG\\_APER\\_4$|\u2060</span>, 1.95 arcsec diameter, S/N =\u00a010). Therefore, lensing galaxies may be undetected in the pixels due to their faintness and/or blending with bright nearby quasar images. We might expect then that some of the quasar pairs identified in this work, and previous STRIDES publications, are lensed quasars. Obtaining deep, high-resolution imaging of all such pairs would be an expensive and potentially inefficient project. However, an indicator of the gravitational lensing hypothesis would be similar long-term variability in the multiple components of a system. Our variability pipeline allows us to consider such objects over a baseline of 4\u00a0yr.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We model all the newly discovered quasar pairs where both components are at the same redshift (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), including those from Anguita et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The variability metric described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2.1</a> is plotted for the components of these NIQs in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a>. They are clearly detected as having multiple variable components, and we might expect that if such systems were lensed quasars, the variability of the images would be similar. However, this neglects the effects of extrinsic variability due to microlensing, difference in time sampling of the true quasar light curve due to the time delay, and the different photometric precision due to flux differences. We inspect each pair looking for similar long-term variability, taking into account a possible time delay causing a shift in the variability. Candidates showing similar variability are DESJ0229+0320 and DESJ2215\u22125204, and those showing seemingly uncorrelated variability are DESJ0122+0358 and DESJ0313\u22122546. These latter two systems have SOAR <em>z</em>-band imaging, which show no signs of lensing galaxies after PSF subtraction. Therefore, the former systems should be given priority for high-resolution imaging follow-up. We warn that extrinsic variability, sampling differences due to the time delay, and chance correlations in distinct quasars, could confuse the signs of lensing.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028972 id=\"203028972\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Variability selection bias</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our light curves have currently only been used to demonstrate the proof of concept of using variability to efficiently discover lensed quasars. Applying such a routine to all close pairs in DES is unfeasible due to the computation time of our pipeline. Kochanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>) suggested difference imaging would be an efficient way to select lensed quasars as extended variable objects. We expect difference imaging will become an effective way to find lensed quasars in current and upcoming full-sky surveys. This naturally raises the question of selection effects from selecting the most variable systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Systems with the faintest intrinsic sources will have the most variable images. For a magnitude-limited survey there is a trade-off between faint sources being more variable, but also having less precise photometry. In practice therefore we expect quasar images with brightnesses near the magnitude limit of a survey to only be robustly detected through their variability if they are high-magnification images. This will favour the selection of quads. We explore such a bias using mock light curves for a DES-like survey, and determine how the reduced \u03c7<sup>2</sup> cut from our DES analysis affects the discovered population. We take the Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) (OM10) mocks and generate light curves using the Damped Random Walk parameters and uncertainties from MacLeod et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) based on source magnitude and redshift. The photometric uncertainties are estimated based on all our <em>i</em>-band measured uncertainties for lensed quasar <em>i</em>-band image magnitudes between 18 and 22.5. Typical uncertainties for images with <em>i</em>\u00a0=\u00a019, 20, 21, 22, and 23 are 0.01, 0.02, 0.04, 0.15, and 0.77 respectively. We assume a pessimistic cadence of one observation per year to understand the selection effects from mock DES data. The light curves are shifted by the relevant time delays and single-epoch magnitudes are sampled. The \u03c7<sup>2</sup> statistic is generated as in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2.1</a> and a system is counted as discovered if at least two images have \u03c7<sup>2</sup> &gt; 3.16. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig16\" data-open=\"fig16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">16</a>, the number of quads and doubles passing this criterion is shown after different numbers of epochs. The numbers naturally increase with more epochs. For a 6 yr survey like DES, we would expect variability to discover \u223c70 quads, and \u223c220 doubles. The middle panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig16\" data-open=\"fig16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">16</a> shows these numbers as a fraction of the total number of quads and doubles that have at least two images brighter than the measured 10\u03c3 single-epoch <em>i</em>-band depth of DES, i.e. 22.78. As expected, the quad fraction is higher due to magnification bias. Requiring just the two brightest images of quads to be the ones detected for variability does not significantly change the results (as shown by the dashed lines in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig16\" data-open=\"fig16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">16</a>), so the higher quad fraction is not due to having more images in quads, and hence having a higher probability of detecting at least two variable images. This analysis includes all mocks in the OM10 catalogue, which contains lenses with Einstein radii down to 0.25 arcsec. While modelling doubles with images separated by more than 0.5 arcsec is feasible for detecting variability, the bright image pairs within quads can be much smaller than this separation. Therefore, we repeat the analysis retaining systems where there exists at least two variable images separated by 0.5 arcsec. The variability bias in quads persists, however the completeness is reduced by about 10\u00a0per\u2009cent, with a 61\u00a0per\u2009cent completeness after a 10 yr survey, as described above.</p>                        <a id=\"203028975\" scrollto-destination=\"203028975\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig16\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 16.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig16.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=ULDCEmV1AGooQmo5FkAIczFIzwegqlWs-S7gJT5ZVd4Yp6~VcOE6gVqVZNESnuQ26gikUPVfrGiwMh4M9LvKbCLuZ0Th4AxXPQbbuz0RCf8UwEyWtvUXUHZ-7CiOzxhov~xQsIfbkPQdtkKoN17C7KLKxsQna2Ee1h8mGk1OCs--c4ILoNti5yGuheU01LNB34raZZyAK~3nS-eLHb-E~Aqoqjutw1TP4mlH79grxzySGPrbrZpR~f1aT~L7EsETq5rddbaDGn2oyqg03ZuUcpWXEohCGiQeZulzEQqgjAWRj9~~wRm3rBOGOvSwlPJ6~GvFhDmA57xeqdSWbpSpEw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: Number of doubles and quads in 5000\u2009deg2 passing the variability threshold condition for at least two images as a function of the number of epochs each separated by exactly 1 yr. Middle: Fraction of systems compared to all systems with at least two images brighter than the measured single-epoch i-band DES depth of 22.78. Bottom: Quad fraction of lenses expected to be discovered with variability techniques. This is much higher than the magnitude-limited sample of lenses, which would have a quad fraction of \u223c17.7\u00a0per\u2009cent. Dashed lines for quads are limiting variability detection to just the two brightest images. This reduces the quad fraction by &lt;1\u00a0per\u2009cent for the DES 6 yr survey, implying the magnification bias alone causes a 6\u00a0per\u2009cent increase in quad fraction over the magnitude-limited sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig16.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028975/staa652fig16.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig16.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028975\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig16.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=WzqvvTho5iwrkczsRAJ3-sj3oVBgUGkNZOgzX9oGcoGRu1QoJ2MzgV3sXOJEnlXw3HyD66lvrSvXtFU-F9ONaTD4SS8ULwS6iyaWHdUIo2OyBxadsw6Xi7G0RrxGJWtv76y2vRmpAFOEsHQPyoZlgI4LV05Ci-11TeWdUq2AOgMi0UCzB6dHt6X6HZbnzPRjBjNWrrO5SRfuwPDZOKPiGciA~ntvyzD1j-1OVHbzA~9097hP21wXssvyYdgVg-J9yauF0vUSNrfLLSrYhiXVH1Mzu4wIZBFm82gZImBmvhsHoIQd3-vOkYFqgzOox2MSwVuglSIMXO6VigWzowfzWQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028975&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig16.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Top: Number of doubles and quads in 5000\u2009deg<sup>2</sup> passing the variability threshold condition for at least two images as a function of the number of epochs each separated by exactly 1 yr. Middle: Fraction of systems compared to all systems with at least two images brighter than the measured single-epoch <em>i</em>-band DES depth of 22.78. Bottom: Quad fraction of lenses expected to be discovered with variability techniques. This is much higher than the magnitude-limited sample of lenses, which would have a quad fraction of \u223c17.7\u00a0per\u2009cent. Dashed lines for quads are limiting variability detection to just the two brightest images. This reduces the quad fraction by &lt;1\u00a0per\u2009cent for the DES 6 yr survey, implying the magnification bias alone causes a 6\u00a0per\u2009cent increase in quad fraction over the magnitude-limited sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig16\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 16.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/m_staa652fig16.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&amp;Signature=ULDCEmV1AGooQmo5FkAIczFIzwegqlWs-S7gJT5ZVd4Yp6~VcOE6gVqVZNESnuQ26gikUPVfrGiwMh4M9LvKbCLuZ0Th4AxXPQbbuz0RCf8UwEyWtvUXUHZ-7CiOzxhov~xQsIfbkPQdtkKoN17C7KLKxsQna2Ee1h8mGk1OCs--c4ILoNti5yGuheU01LNB34raZZyAK~3nS-eLHb-E~Aqoqjutw1TP4mlH79grxzySGPrbrZpR~f1aT~L7EsETq5rddbaDGn2oyqg03ZuUcpWXEohCGiQeZulzEQqgjAWRj9~~wRm3rBOGOvSwlPJ6~GvFhDmA57xeqdSWbpSpEw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: Number of doubles and quads in 5000\u2009deg2 passing the variability threshold condition for at least two images as a function of the number of epochs each separated by exactly 1 yr. Middle: Fraction of systems compared to all systems with at least two images brighter than the measured single-epoch i-band DES depth of 22.78. Bottom: Quad fraction of lenses expected to be discovered with variability techniques. This is much higher than the magnitude-limited sample of lenses, which would have a quad fraction of \u223c17.7\u00a0per\u2009cent. Dashed lines for quads are limiting variability detection to just the two brightest images. This reduces the quad fraction by &lt;1\u00a0per\u2009cent for the DES 6 yr survey, implying the magnification bias alone causes a 6\u00a0per\u2009cent increase in quad fraction over the magnitude-limited sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig16.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203028975/staa652fig16.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig16.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203028975\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/3/10.1093_mnras_staa652/1/staa652fig16.jpeg?Expires=1611464529&Signature=WzqvvTho5iwrkczsRAJ3-sj3oVBgUGkNZOgzX9oGcoGRu1QoJ2MzgV3sXOJEnlXw3HyD66lvrSvXtFU-F9ONaTD4SS8ULwS6iyaWHdUIo2OyBxadsw6Xi7G0RrxGJWtv76y2vRmpAFOEsHQPyoZlgI4LV05Ci-11TeWdUq2AOgMi0UCzB6dHt6X6HZbnzPRjBjNWrrO5SRfuwPDZOKPiGciA~ntvyzD1j-1OVHbzA~9097hP21wXssvyYdgVg-J9yauF0vUSNrfLLSrYhiXVH1Mzu4wIZBFm82gZImBmvhsHoIQd3-vOkYFqgzOox2MSwVuglSIMXO6VigWzowfzWQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203028975&ar=5801039&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa652fig16.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Top: Number of doubles and quads in 5000\u2009deg<sup>2</sup> passing the variability threshold condition for at least two images as a function of the number of epochs each separated by exactly 1 yr. Middle: Fraction of systems compared to all systems with at least two images brighter than the measured single-epoch <em>i</em>-band DES depth of 22.78. Bottom: Quad fraction of lenses expected to be discovered with variability techniques. This is much higher than the magnitude-limited sample of lenses, which would have a quad fraction of \u223c17.7\u00a0per\u2009cent. Dashed lines for quads are limiting variability detection to just the two brightest images. This reduces the quad fraction by &lt;1\u00a0per\u2009cent for the DES 6 yr survey, implying the magnification bias alone causes a 6\u00a0per\u2009cent increase in quad fraction over the magnitude-limited sample.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The absolute numbers are conservative since we have only used one band. Using the <em>g</em>-band would be best for detecting variability, however this is the band for which we have found the PSF most difficult to model. Furthermore, we have only considered intrinsic variations as a method for detecting lensed quasars. Extrinsic variations from microlensing will make these light curves more variable, making our estimates more conservative.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This variability bias will have an impact on the subset of lensed quasars that will have their time delays measured via LSST. Early predictions from OM10 suggested up to 3000 lensed quasars will have measured time delays in LSST. A tested prediction came from the Time-Delay Challenge, which created thousands of mock LSST lensed quasar light curves with known time delays, then given to the community for blind time-delay retrieval (Dobler et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Liao et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Based on teams\u2019 correct retrievals of time delays, approximately 400 robust measurements will be expected from LSST; however, the mock light curves drew variability parameters uniformly from observed ranges, rather than using their correlations with intrinsic luminosity. It is unclear how this would affect the numbers of robust time-delay measurements, though the quad fraction within this sample will be higher because of the same causes of variability selection bias. A multiplicity-biased sample of lensed quasars with time delays, as expected from LSST, can lead to biases in cosmological parameters without careful consideration of priors in lens modelling (Collett\u00a0&amp; Cunnington <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203028978 id=\"203028978\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented the spectroscopic and high-resolution imaging follow-up from the STRIDES 2017\u20132018 campaign, discovering 10 new lensed quasars and 12 quasar pairs. Ten of these pairs have quasars at the same redshift, and further imaging might reveal lensing galaxies. Of particular interest in the lensed quasar sample is a quadruply imaged quasar, DESJ0053\u22122012, with a source redshift of 3.8, and a triply imaged 6.8 arcsec separation lensed quasar with all images detected by <em>Gaia</em>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After the end of the follow-up campaign, we applied a parametric modelling pipeline (any combination of point sources and galaxies) to determine the level of variability in individual components in any system. Applying this to known lensed quasars and spectroscopically confirmed quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star pairs in the DES footprint, we provide a prescription for removing 94\u00a0per\u2009cent of the latter from future spectroscopic follow-up campaigns, while retaining all lensed quasars. However, we note that future campaigns targeting a complete sample of lensed quasars with difference imaging techniques \u2013 as might be applied to the LSST \u2013 will need to take into account the variability bias of their search. This will require a good understanding of the variability distribution of the sources, and the magnifications due to realistic lensing galaxies. Such searches will be biased towards high-magnification systems, since there exists a strong anticorrelation between intrinsic luminosity and variability.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In our 2016/2017 campaign our confirmation rate was 6\u201335\u00a0per\u2009cent (with spread due to NIQs and inconclusive systems), while in 2017/2018 it was (10\u201327)/65\u00a0=\u00a015\u201341\u00a0per\u2009cent. Future selection should show significant improvement in efficiency based on our variability modelling technique and new auxiliary data sets, such as <em>Gaia</em> data release 2. The DES recently completed survey operations after 6 yr so we will soon extend the baseline of these studies by 50\u00a0per\u2009cent, which will improve the certainty of contaminant systems, prioritization of follow-up of quasar pairs as potential lensed quasars, and detection of lensing galaxies through deeper stacked imaging. Future improvements on extracting variability from single-epoch images may come from non-parametric reconstructions of the PSF (Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and/or extended light emission (Cantale et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), or by modelling difference images (Kochanek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>; Lacki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Chao et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203028982 id=\"203028982\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This work has made use of data from the European Space Agency (ESA) mission <em>Gaia</em> (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.cosmos.esa.int/gaia\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.cosmos.esa.int/gaia</a>), processed by the <em>Gaia</em> Data Processing and Analysis Consortium (DPAC, <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/gaia/dpac/consortium\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/gaia/dpac/consortium</a>). Funding for the DPAC has been provided by national institutions, in particular the institutions participating in the <em>Gaia</em> Multilateral Agreement. Some of the data presented herein were obtained at the W. M. Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership among the California Institute of Technology, the University of California and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by the generous financial support of the W. M. Keck Foundation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Funding for the DES Projects has been provided by the U.S. Department of Energy, the U.S. National Science Foundation, the Ministry of Science and Education of Spain, the Science and Technology Facilities Council of the United Kingdom, the Higher Education Funding Council for England, the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Kavli Institute of Cosmological Physics at the University of Chicago, the Center for Cosmology and Astro-Particle Physics at the Ohio State University, the Mitchell Institute for Fundamental Physics and Astronomy at Texas A&amp;M University, Financiadora de Estudos e Projetos, Funda\u00e7\u00e3o Carlos Chagas Filho de Amparo \u00e0 Pesquisa do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cient\u00edfico e Tecnol\u00f3gico and the Minist\u00e9rio da Ci\u00eancia, Tecnologia e Inova\u00e7\u00e3o, the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft, and the Collaborating Institutions in the Dark Energy Survey.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Collaborating Institutions are Argonne National Laboratory, the University of California at Santa Cruz, the University of Cambridge, Centro de Investigaciones Energ\u00e9ticas, Medioambientales y Tecnol\u00f3gicas-Madrid, the University of Chicago, University College London, Universit\u00e4t M\u00fcnchen and the associated Excellence Cluster Universe, the University of Michigan, the National Optical Astronomy Observatory, the University of Nottingham, The Ohio State University, the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Portsmouth, SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, Stanford University, the University of Sussex, Texas A&amp;M University, and the OzDES Membership Consortium.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on observations obtained at the Southern Astrophysical Research (SOAR) telescope, which is a joint project of the Minist\u00e9rio da Ci\u00eancia, Tecnologia, Inova\u00e7\u00f5es e Comunica\u00e7\u00f5es (MCTIC) do Brasil, the U.S. National Optical Astronomy Observatory (NOAO), the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC), and Michigan State University (MSU). VM acknowledges the support of the Centro de Astrof\u00edsica de Valpara\u00edso.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The DES data management system is supported by the National Science Foundation under grant numbers AST-1138766 and AST-1536171. The DES participants from Spanish institutions are partially supported by MINECO under grants AYA2015-71825, ESP2015-66861, FPA2015-68048, SEV-2016-0588, SEV-2016-0597, and MDM-2015-0509, some of which include ERDF funds from the European Union. IFAE is partially funded by the CERCA program of the Generalitat de Catalunya. We acknowledge support from the Brazilian Instituto Nacional de Ci\u00eanciae Tecnologia (INCT) e-Universe (CNPq grant 465376/2014-2).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This study is based in part on observations at Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory, National Optical Astronomy Observatory, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy (AURA) under a cooperative agreement with the National Science Foundation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work is supported by the Swiss National Science Foundation (SNSF). We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This manuscript has been authored by Fermi Research Alliance, LLC under Contract No. DE-AC02-07CH11359 with the U.S. Department of Energy, Office of Science, Office of High Energy Physics.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203028992 id=\"203028992\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.ast.cam.ac.uk/ioa/research/lensedquasars/\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.ast.cam.ac.uk/ioa/research/lensedquasars/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">STRIDES is a Dark Energy Survey Broad External Collaboration; L.</div></span> et al.\u00a0.</span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">AJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">140</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1868</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1088/0004-6256/140/6/1868\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1088/0004-6256/140/6/1868</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0004-6256/140/6/1868\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1088%2F0004-6256%2F140%2F6%2F1868\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-6256%2F140%2F6%2F1868\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203028999 id=\"203028999\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>APPENDIX A: ALL OBSERVED TARGETS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA2\" data-open=\"tblA2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a> list all inconclusive systems and contaminant systems, respectively, each with spectroscopic follow-up. While all systems show multiple components in the imaging data, spectroscopy does not always resolve these components and are marked as blended in the outcome. Systems are inconclusive either due to blending or due to lack of signal to noise.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2009</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2009</p>                        <a id=\"203029003\" scrollto-destination=\"203029003\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tblA1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tblA1\" data-id=\"tblA1\"><span class=\"label\">Table A1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inconclusive candidates.          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203029004\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203029005 id=\"203029005\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>APPENDIX B: ASTROMETRY AND PHOTOMETRY</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblB1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblB1\" data-open=\"tblB1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a> provides the astrometry from the best available imaging data and DES photometry for each lens system. The uncertainties on quasar photometry reflect the standard deviation of multi-epoch magnitude values, or in the case of only one epoch fitting being retained, the uncertainty on that single-epoch magnitude. In the case of the lens galaxy, the photometry and uncertainty are given for the most precise single-epoch band.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2009</p>                        <a id=\"203029008\" scrollto-destination=\"203029008\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tblB1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tblB1\" data-id=\"tblB1\"><span class=\"label\">Table B1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Astrometry and photometry of all confirmed lensed quasars. Magnitudes are in the AB system. All photometry is from DES. Astrometry is from NIRC2 (DESJ0246, DESJ0245, DESJ0340), SOAR (J0053, J0150, J0407, J0501, J0600), or DES (DESJ0112). The photometric uncertainties are the standard deviation of magnitudes across all measured epochs. Stated flux ratios are from the best imaging data.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"chapter-para\">Median parameter values with 1\u03c3 uncertainties for mass model and galaxy light profiles of confirmed lensed quasars. <em>b</em>\u00a0=\u00a0Einstein radius, PA\u00a0=\u00a0position angle (East of North), <em>q</em> = axial ratio, and \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a0magnification. Given the group lensing DESJ0340\u22122545, more detailed mass models are described in the text and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span>5 for this system. The model we use for DESJ0053\u22122012 is a 2 SIE model, as described in the text. For this model, we expect a good fit to have \u03c7<sup>2</sup> \u2248 3.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: Green Street, Urbana, IL 61801, USA; National Center for Supercomputing Applications, 1205 West Clark St., Urbana, IL 61801, USA), CG(Department of Astrophysical Sciences, Princeton University, Peyton Hall, Princeton, NJ 08544, USA), CH(Department of Physics, Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, USA; SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, Menlo Park, CA 94025, USA), CI(Centro de Investigaciones Energ\u00e9ticas, Medioambientales y Tecnol\u00f3gicas (CIEMAT), Madrid, Spain), CJ(Department of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA), CK(Institut d'Estudis Espacials de Catalunya (IEEC), E-08034 Barcelona, Spain; Institute of Space Sciences (ICE, CSIC), Campus UAB, Carrer de Can Magrans, s/n, E-08193 Barcelona, Spain), CL(School of Physics and Astronomy, University of Southampton, Southampton SO17 1BJ, UK), CM(Physics Department, Brandeis University, 415 South Street, Waltham, MA 02453, USA), CN(Computer Science and Mathematics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831, USA), CO(Department of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA), CP(Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory, National Optical Astronomy Observatory, Casilla 603, La Serena, Chile)"], "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "methods: observational", "quasars: general", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2020MNRAS.494.3491L", "volume": "494", "Title": "The STRong lensing Insights into the Dark Energy Survey (STRIDES) 2017/2018 follow-up campaign: discovery of 10 lensed quasars and 10 quasar pairs", "abstract": "We report the results of the STRong lensing Insights into the Dark Energy Survey (STRIDES) follow-up campaign of the late 2017/early 2018 season. We obtained spectra of 65 lensed quasar candidates with ESO Faint Object Spectrograph and Camera 2 on the NTT and Echellette Spectrograph and Imager on Keck, confirming 10 new lensed quasars and 10 quasar pairs. Eight lensed quasars are doubly imaged with source redshifts between 0.99 and 2.90, one is triply imaged (DESJ0345-2545, z = 1.68), and one is quadruply imaged (quad: DESJ0053-2012, z = 3.8). Singular isothermal ellipsoid models for the doubles, based on high-resolution imaging from SAMI on Southern Astrophysical Research Telescope or Near InfraRed Camera 2 on Keck, give total magnifications between 3.2 and 5.6, and Einstein radii between 0.49 and 1.97 arcsec. After spectroscopic follow-up, we extract multi-epoch grizY photometry of confirmed lensed quasars and contaminant quasar + star pairs from DES data using parametric multiband modelling, and compare variability in each system's components. By measuring the reduced \u03c7<SUP>2</SUP> associated with fitting all epochs to the same magnitude, we find a simple cut on the less variable component that retains all confirmed lensed quasars, while removing 94 per cent of contaminant systems. Based on our spectroscopic follow-up, this variability information improves selection of lensed quasars and quasar pairs from 34-45 per cent to 51-70 per cent, with most remaining contaminants being star-forming galaxies. Using mock lensed quasar light curves we demonstrate that selection based only on variability will over-represent the quad fraction by 10 per cent over a complete DES magnitude-limited sample, explained by the magnification bias and hence lower luminosity/more variable sources in quads."}}
